reviewText:
What is Hatoful Boyfriend? Hatoful Boyfriend is a bird dating sim.

I purchased this because I thought it would be funny to say that I was playing a bird dating sim.  There wasn’t suppose to be any real feelings behind this purchase, it was all in jest.

I launched the game and quickly got to the bad ending.  I figured I should at least complete one or two “good” endings before I uninstalled the game and abandoned it to be just another game in my library.  To accomplish my goal of being able to complete a good ending, I quickly made a “birds.txt” where I would list everybody in the story with a couple words to allow me to remember who was who.

Ryouta : Childhood friend, sick
Sakuya : ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥
Yuuya : Works in infirmiry, upperclassmen, half brother of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, flirt
Nageki : Library silent dude
San : RUN RUN RUN RUN RUN
Kazuaki : Homeroom / math teacher, falls asleep
Shuu : Doctor


Referencing this “cheat sheet”, I was able to get a good ending fairly easily.  I repeated myself, this time going for a different ending...sometime in this third playthrough, something changed.

By the end of that ending, I was actually enjoying what I was doing.  This “Joke of a game” was actually drawing me in, not because of “bird dating sim”, but because of the actual plot and the compelling characters.  My cheat sheet was pointless, I knew all the names.  Everybirdie had their own personality, and their stories had wildly different outcomes, yet were all tied together to help reveal a plot that actually mattered.

As you play through the game more, and achieve different endings you find little bits and pieces about the world.  You read how birds became the dominant lifeform on the planet, how the human race almost fell to extinction, and how bird politics work.

Each story feel completely different.  They all showcase a huge variety of emotions and social conditions.  One story / ending exists entirely for humor, and no deep thought is put into anything.  You are able to laugh your way through a 20 minute story and have a great time.  You re-roll your game, and suddenly your story is filled with great sorrow between all the funny bird puns.  Sadness then turns into happiness as your story becomes complete.  Re-roll again, now you are exploring yet more bird puns, but this time also the impossible expectations sometimes forced onto oneself from their family.  Re-roll, now genocide is brought into the fold.  Re-roll, we are happy and excited again.

What the hell just happened?  This game somehow managed to put an actual fantastic plot full of emotion and lessons of how the world works into...a bird dating simulator.  Somehow this completely over the top game idea is completely overlooked the more you play it and fall in love with it.



Everybirdie should download this game and try it out because “lol bird dating sim”.  You’ll be amazed as the joke suddenly starts being enjoyable and the fact that everyone is a bird spouting bird puns is able to be completely overlooked.

What is Hatoful Boyfriend? Hatoful Boyfriend is a fantastic game filled with more emotion and story than it should possibly contain.

reviewText:
Hatoful Boyfriend is more nuanced and compelling than it has any right to be.

Its outrageous concept is so over the top that it’s hard to view the game as anything more than a joke; something amusing but mostly held together by the mere fact of its existence. But these preconceptions, strung along by even its own marketing and description, are hiding the shockingly well written and emotionally stirring narrative underneath.

To be entirely clear, it is in part exactly what it appears to be: an otome dating simulator/visual novel, set in a world where birds have evolved to be the most intelligent species and humans have been mostly driven to extinction. Playing as the lone human student at Pigeonation Academy, you are tasked with going about your day, trying to scrape by in your schoolwork while wooing the bird of your dreams.

It’s an intentionally laughable idea, and one which at first can seem so ridiculous as to turn those less drawn to Japan’s stranger exports away, but its one which never dissolves into idiotic bird lover pandering (assuming that’s a thing that exists) or outright stupidity with its writing. Hatoful Boyfriend is entirely aware of its own absurdity, and treats it almost as an afterthought, to the point that the fact these characters are nearly entirely birds became irrelevant at least as far as being a very odd novelty.

Hatoful Boyfriend’s writing is exceptional, both hilarious and comical, and heart wrenchingly sad and contemplative. Though it begins as little more than a silly teenage romance, it spends this time crafting characters that you come to care about, before hurling them into a plot darker and more precarious than I ever could have imagine. While there are certainly parts (and entire storylines) within the game which are nothing but comedy, allowing the humorous and charming side of the game to take the spotlight for a moment and provide more than a few laughs, it was when the subject matter moved away from this silliness that I began to finally see the hidden brilliance of the game’s writer.

It’s shocking to even consider at first, and even now as I’m writing this I’m rather stunned at what Hatoful Boyfriend manages to do with its narrative, but it handles it's incredibly dark material with incredible grace and consideration. Calculated genocide, mass murder and biological experimentation, interspecies racism, and the value of family are not only touched upon, but discussed at length and in such a way as to not only allow you to take them seriously within the game’s context, but actually emphasize and become emotionally invested in the avian characters that once seemed so innocent and comical.

Hatoful Boyfriend made me laugh; it made me smile and appreciate its subtlety; and it made me cry. The spectrum of emotions I experienced throughout my handful of playthroughs (which should be considered a requisite, as you will miss the vast majority of the game’s content if you only go through it once) was something I never imagined this game to be capable of. It kept me playing for hours on end, up late into the night, and I’m still attempting to process all that I witnessed. It could very well be the apotheosis of a game you shouldn’t judge by its cover, and something that everybirdie ought to at least give a chance before writing it off as something it by and large is anything but.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
Before Hatoful Boyfriend, I was a happily married man with a home, a well-paying job, a wife, and two kids.

Then, the eve before my birthday, a close friend had stealthily bought Hatoful Boyfriend and sent it to me, thinking it'd be a funny early birthday present. I decided to humor him, and booted up the game on that one fateful Saturday night.

My house burned down, I lost my job, my wife divorced me and took custody of the children, and my pizza delivery guy was late.

I'm now pregnant with my 17th child from my new pigeon hasubando and am currently living in a giant, underwater nest filled with kawaii mutant human-bird baby hybrids that feed off of human flesh and Lego blocks.

10/10.

It's okay.

reviewText:
this game is an emotional trap. you buy it because the idea of a dating simulator with pigeons is 'LOL SO RANDOM!!11 XD' and full of 'teh lulz', but then you accidentally end up playing a parody game that turns out to be far better than the majority of material it's actually imitating.

the writing is thoughtful and well-balanced, containing humor of the rare 'actually funny' type, which will result in feelings of warm attachment to the characters... before TWISTING THE KNIFE OF FEELINGS DEEPLY as a tragedy of Shakespearean proportions overwhelms the plotline arc and cast.

the writing also has a highly surprising amount of depth, as the characters (including your own) must make some morally ambiguous choices, and even the most immoral characters have a few redeeming, wholly human features to their personalities which make them relatable and strangely likable.

there are 16 different endings to the story that are achieved based on the choices you make, with one 'true ending' and 15 'alternate endings'; notably, the alternate endings to this story are cleverly interwoven into the 'true' ending plotline, as with each new ending you discover, you are given new revelations that consistently give you deeper insight into the events that unfold prior to the finale of the 'true' plotline. this means that there is an actual reader's value that goes beyond shallow 'what if' ideas to following every path to its ending, which is fairly uncommon in the genre of multiple-choice story games.

the art is also clean, colorful and high quality, and the music sets the tone nicely. honestly the only thing i could wish for is that it was fully voiced (it isn't).

recommended for people who actually enjoy good stories in visual novels, as opposed to the endless list of VNs with vapid, soulless storylines that rely on a cast of waifus and husbandos to appeal to buyers... although, you have been warned- after playing this game, the odds that you will have horrifyingly/ heartbreakingly fallen in love with your first ever 'pigeon husbando' are high...

reviewText:
I share a similar story with many other reviewers here. I bought this game for the laughs. I mean, a pigeon dating sim? I assumed I'd have fun with it for a couple of hours and then be done. I was not expecting what happened next.

Cons I must admit that there are negatives, and I will point them out before I praise the game. To start off, I'm not sure if this can be considered a negative (I think it's a positive), but a few of the story lines seem to be created merely for amusement and humour. They make no sense, and are there as a joke. However, If you are looking for something that is 100% serious, you're in the wrong place, and I have absolutely no clue why you would be here in the first place. Anyway, the interface and skill point system is simple, but they do the job. There are a few spelling and grammar errors scattered throughout, which may be distracting, but they are far and few between. As well, the starting routes are short and perhaps shallow. I recommend you try to complete all of the endings in order to see the Bad Boys Love" bonus ending and the epilogue.

Pros Despite all of that

reviewText:
To some, Hatoful Boyfriend is a game.
To some, Hatoful Boyfriend is a fandom.

To me, none of this amounts. It does not even come close.



Let me tell you how my adventure went...



A little background on me. I used to be a human soldier for the United States. I lost my legs in Afghanistan (Landmine+Humvee=Not Good). After coming back home to a wife who cheated and wanted a divorce, I fell into a deep depression. I thought my life was over and my existence had no purpose. That was, until I found this game.



I thought this game was a joke. A bird dating sim?!? This'll be hilarious. It was even on sale! I invited some close friends over, we needed to kek together at this glorious joke.

We booted up the game and set the graphics quality to fantastic" Upon hitting play

but the game didn't stop. Because... we were the game.

reviewText:
My Hatoful Boyfriend Adventure
Before playing: Haha, goofy bird-dating game!
San's ending: Haha, I dated a goofy bird!
Ryouta's ending: Haha, I-- oh, that was quite touching actually
Nageki's ending: o-oh
Yuuya's ending: oh, er, that's a bit-
Shuu's ending: ...blimey
BBL ending: h-hold me

In all seriousness- and I know there's no point saying it because however sincere I am, I won't be believed- Hatoful Boyfriend has one of the darkest plots I've ever known. It's a shame there's a lot of repetition to get through before you get to the real meat of the game, but it's worth it for the character development and laughs you'll have along the way. Laughs and tears. Mostly tears.

reviewText: When people hear the term games as art" they generally make the mistake of lumping everything into the same visual category. Sometimes art is in the form of a concept or idea and not just an optical quality
date: and it's in this sense that I highly regard Hatoful Boyfriend as a work of art. It takes a tired and cliched concept and reworks it into a thought provoking and never before seen idea that manages to be both humorously satirical and affectingly sentimental
recommended: causing the general public to reconsider and ponder the meaning of a mostly mocked genre.\n\nSome may discount the games merits based on the corny puns
hoursPlayed: and these people miss the point entirely. What makes Hatoful Boyfriend so damn funny
voteText: so artfully clever
helpfulPercent: and so hard to stop smiling at is the overall concept of what's happening and the way the emotionally driven story is delivered. The idea of seeing such seriously toned dialogue combined with the strange and surreal imagery of a school of pigeons is wildly outside of the box
votesHelpful: and to anyone with an imagination is at first incredibly entertaining. What really takes the player by surprise is the emotional draw the story has on you in the end for what at first was such a seemingly laughable and satirical plot.\n\nHatoful Boyfriend isn't just a satire or a mockery
votesTotal: it's not just one big comedic joke like some might intially believe. The characters are written well and manage to shine with more personality and.. humanity(?) than what we're used to seeing in the generally shallow world of anime dating sims
votesFunny: which is what makes the experience feel even more bizarre
commentsCount: strange
column16: yet memorable given it's subject matter. It manages to feel more real and authentic than even the most sensible or conventional games in this form of interactive storytelling.\n\nThe strange feeling evoked by Hatoful Boyfriend of feeling a growing emotional attachment towards something so seemingly overlooked as a pigeon or bird in a video game is one I'll remember. People with no connection or empathy for the animal kingdom my find it hard to swallow the ongoings of St. Pigeonation and won't take away anything of value from this quirky change of pace needed in gaming
column17: but those with an open mind and heart to the topic will come away with a new found respect and admiration for a species generally viewed as insignificant or often misunderstood.\n\nIf you're the type who isn't too concerned with artistic and strange new takes on old genres
column18: or you're one of those gamer types who enjoys the same-old-same-old while fearing changes to the industry then by all means skip this and play what you usually play. For people who want something new in the medium and want to see differences to gaming that allow a wider variety of people into the world of interactive experiences we call games then Hatoful Boyfriend is something you'll want to check out."

reviewText:
The creators of Hatoful Boyfriend made a huge gamble.

Most of the people who buy this game just play it for the LOLs and to be able to brag about playing a dating simulator with birds (it's a great conversation starter, alright). They enjoy the derpiness for a bit, reach one ending and then move on to another game, some of them maybe a little bit disappointed.

Well, it takes a few more completed routes to notice there's something really weird going on - you know, besides the whole bird-ruled society thing, and it takes ALL the character endings for the game to really start!

Finally, all your questions will be answered! Why are the birds in charge? What happened to humans? Why was a human girl admitted to this super prestigious birds-only school? Why do the courses served in the school cafeteria have such morbid names? Why does the math teacher smell like bleach?

If I hadn't decided to get all the achievements before being done with this game, I'd never have known how interesting it really is. As I said, a huge gamble on the creators' side, but in my case it paid off.

Now, for those who are planning on playing this game, can you promise to actually complete it?
>Yes
>Yes
>Yes

Thanks! I knew I could count on you!

reviewText:
Every once in a while, you run into something that challenges your expectations in ways you couldn’t have possibly expected. It wears the surface layer like a wolf in pigeon’s clothing, promising a few quick laughs through the trappings of a dolled up Visual Novel featuring an all-bird cast. And if you were to think of it as nothing more, what with all of the pink upholstery and hearts surrounding every element of the game’s outward presentation, then no one could blame you. But it also counts on this charade to drag the player into something beneath its skin. Hatoful Boyfriend is indeed a game about attending an all-bird high school as the only human in the academy. Yet, if one cares to look above, they’ll see a murder of crows circling overhead.

Hatoful Boyfriend will appear familiar to anyone who has played a Visual Novel or two. Once you’ve started a new game, it will ask for your name, introduce you to the majority of characters in a warm and friendly environment, and generally settle you into daily life at St. PigeoNation. Navigation works similarly to the thousands which have come before it. You progress forward by clicking or hitting enter as a dialog box completes to display the next one and advance the story, occasionally make a selection to build your stats or guide which bird you will chase for their affection. There’s also the option to save and load, as well as alter some basic settings, and a convenient fast-forward button in the upper corner, should you wish to skip over dialog you’ve already seen. And of course, branching paths which all lead to their own endings, all depending on choices you make.

The first trick Hatoful Boyfriend pulls out of its hat is how short a single run can last. The very first run I completed took me about an hour in total, which draws the player in, promising quick trips down alternative paths to collect all of the pigeon husbando~ hearts. This is exactly what it wants you to do. Only going through the game once wouldn’t allow for the seams in the feathered costume begin to show, so it pushes you towards seeking every han- er, wing, you possibly can. With every successful unique ending, you’re rewarded with curious snippets in the “archive” section in the main menu. Between the diary entries and newspaper clippings, it’s trying to warn you. Only, we’re too occupied as players staring at the plumes of tail feathers to see the forest for the trees.

And it’s hard not to. The game’s use of standard visual novel/anime characterizations intelligently manipulates the player into wanting to chase down the Tsundere French transfer student, the plucky best friend you’ve known since you were both younger, the goth kid who speaks a language all his own, and even the creepy one who mutters statements under his breath that would be admissible evidence in court. Down each path, there’s plenty of humorous dialog and heart-tugging character development. The fact that they are all birds instead of humans or anime portraits just pulls the covers over your eyes when the real drama finally hits. They’re all entertainingly written, even if they stay extremely close to the tropes that birthed them. Let’s not allow the down comforter to be pulled over our eyes though. Several of the paths lean heavily into exposing Hatoful Boyfriend’s big secret, which is given to the player after certain endings have been cleared.

BBL mode, known as “Bad Boys Love”, is what Hatoful Boyfriend is really building towards. All of the characters you meet, all of the interactions you have, they all lead down the path towards BBL mode’s story. To explain what exactly BBL is would be to spoil the true meat and potatoes of the game, and thus I can’t in good conscience actually explain it to you. Even if I did tell you, in great detail, what it is and what happens during it, there’s no way you’d actually believe me. It is a much bigger bird than the others, with secrets tucked between every feather. I’ve seen many reviews not even mention it in fear of spoiling it but I feel as though that isn’t enough to truly entice someone into playing the game. Much like Hatoful Boyfriend’s tricks, I have spent most of this review building up to BBL mode simply to get you interested in what lies beyond that cage door. In order for you to discover the truth, however, you’ll have to spread your wings on your own.

It might just be because I let my guard down from the pigeon-centric cast but Hatoful Boyfriend left me feeling shaken. What I’d gone through was both hilarious and frightening at the same time. Just keep your wits about you, reinforce your constitution, and carve it into your soul. Hatoful Boyfriend is not just a dating sim where your boyfriends all have winged limbs and beaks. It’s an example of playing to the strengths and comforts of a genre while turning convention on its head to have the stork deliver a story so full of twists that it took me 3 sheets of paper and small handwriting to keep track of it all.


Did you enjoy this review? If so, be sure to stop by at RGZ.CA to see all of my reviews, as well as the work of the other writers! http://rgz.ca/gaming/hatoful-boyfriend-review-this-bird-has-flown/

reviewText:
At first glance, it looks like a silly dating sim with birds.

At second glance, it still looks like a silly dating sim with birds.

Play a few hours in, it STILL looks like a silly dating sim with birds.

Play more than a few hours in, and suddenly it becomes something wonderful, something beautiful, something that actually helped me fight the depression I've been struggling with for years.

It's like My Little Pony or Monster Girl Quest, people take it at face value and wonder what the hell is wrong with humanity. But only little kids will say that they don't like carrots without ever tasting them. It might take a while to find, but this game has Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons levels of story and emotional content lurking within. All you need to do is try it.

Some proof: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ynGhR81w-ZE

reviewText:
Lunacy! Madness!
This game. This game right here.
At first it comes as your typical senseless japanese otome game with birds only good for dropping a few laughs.
Well just let me kindly point out how WRONG you are.
You might as well know at this point what it is about. You are the only female human in a school for birds. You make friends, you follow the different routes, you have different endings. We get it.
BUT THOSE ENDINGS.
This ain't no game for kids. I'm not saying bestiality takes place, but those endings will stick with you for a while. Some more than others. Some WAY more than others.
And once you have reached all 14 endings....

The real game starts

And I'm by no means exaggerating in here. You have not started playing Hatoful Boyfriend unless you have unlocked the BBL storyline. If you found the previous 14 routes to be superb, this one will make them all look like prepubertal school girls. And man it's ♥♥♥♥ing worth it. This game is absolutely great. Plot-twists everywhere, laughs, tears, angst, fear... you will certainly find playing with talking birds so natural it will not mess with the plot and game experience, trust me on this.
Confound you if you are yet hesitating on acquiring this masterpiece!

reviewText:
To be entirely honest, I got this game as a joke. I mean, really, who seriously buys a PIGEON DATING SIM? I thought this would just be a lighthearted, funny game I could play for some kicks and giggles. Don't get me wrong, the actual romance storylines were pretty hilarious in nature, like the part in Ryota's romance where you get a peek at his job (if you've played the game you'll know what I'm talking about).

Honestly, I wasn't expecting much from this though besides the joke about it being a pigeon dating sim... until I got to the BBL storyline. Without spoiling anything, let me just say the BBL storyline/ending has nothing to do with romance. It gives you a huge insight on all the characters, their pasts, and how they're all connected. It's rather long compared to just romancing one of your bird companions, but well worth playing through. The BBL storyline/ending does not give you much choice options and is more like a visual novel, but I really appreciated how the developer chose to make it. For me, it turned this simple pigeon dating sim into something far more complicated and intriguing. It is also the reason that this game has become one of my favorite games I've played in a long while.

I give this game a 10/10 purely for the BBL storyline/ending.

11/10 for being a pigeon dating sim :p

reviewText:
I appear to be the first negative reviewer to have completed the game in its entirety.  This game has two distinct parts, the dating sim and the Bad Boys Love secret route unlocked by romancing every bird possible.

The first part is simply too short to be entertaining.  Any route can be read in about an hour going at a relaxed pace, but there is significant overlap between routes, including sections that have no effect on the particular route you're playing, so I found myself skipping more and more as I replayed.  This also caused me to inadvertantly skip content I hadn't read before, because some sections have multiple outcomes but start out the same way regardless of route.  There is no way to go back to content accidentally skipped without reloading or starting a new game and it simply wasn't interesting enough to worth bothering to find out why I was faced with the choice of telling Okosan convenience store" or "grocery store" and I could infer it had something to do with pudding anyway.

Consequently
date: there just isn't enough time to give any character depth and there's no challenge to complete a route.  By the time you finish a route
recommended: you feel like you were merely introduced to the character.  Picking routes are also very obvious and there is never any difficulty in seducing the various birds
hoursPlayed: unless you can't figure out that picking every opportunity to spend time with your desired bird is necessary to romance them.  The routes I enjoyed most
voteText: Okosan
helpfulPercent: Shuu
votesHelpful: and Anghel
votesTotal: stood out because they were simply the most oddball.  For a game that is billed as a comedy
votesFunny: most routes utilize stereotypical melodrama.  Bird puns and pop culture references abound
commentsCount: but there's really nothing laugh out loud funny in Hatoful Boyfriend and at best you'll smirk a lot.\n\nThere is a very simple stat system
column16: raised by choosing between three elective classes at regular intervals and in a couple of events that likewise present three choices which raise a stat.  The stats serve one purpose
column17: which is to determine whether you get a normal ending or an extended ending.  Extended endings require you to raise one stat to maximum and reward you with an extra scene that was implied in the normal ending anyway.  Each ending has a separate achievement and you can't get both the normal ending and extended ending achievements in one go
column18: so you have to play the same route twice in order to get all the achievements and unlock the Bad Boys Love extended ending.  I wasted part of my life to get the BBL extended ending and it was just as disappointing as the other extended endings.\n\nThe second part of the game
column19: the Bad Boys Love secret route is much more interesting
column20: but by the time I unlocked it I was already tired of the game.  I trudged on in hopes that it would be good and it was
column21: kind of.  The game suddenly takes a much darker tone
column22: reveals how the world came to be dominated by talking birds
column23: and becomes a mystery story.  It seems interesting for a while
column24: but as all the threads come together it becomes a soap opera for the ages.  Characters are revealed to be secret brothers
column34: there are no secret comas to complete the cliche pantheon.  I got the distinct impression that the first half of the game was written primarily to introduce the characters so that the meandering mysteries wouldn't simply baffle readers.\n\nAll in all
column35: Hatoful Boyfriend wasn't an altogether terrible game
column36: but it just wasn't worth the money and I got it in a 50% off sale.  I will likely never read it again and would forget about it entirely if Steam didn't keep it in my library forever.  As some consolation
column37: the trading cards were surprisingly valuable and I was able to quickly sell them for about $1.50.\n\nIf you don't mind a lot of repetition
column38: love every visual novel no matter what
column41: pick up just about any other visual novel on Steam.  Even some of the free ones are more entertaining than Hatoful Boyfriend.\n\n4/10"

reviewText:
Hatoful Boyfriend is a game about a girl who wants to smooch birds.

It is also so much more than that, but it is important that you go into Hatoful Boyfriend with at least the baseline expectation of pursuing human-on-bird smooching. And it is glorious.
Hatoful Boyfriend is a PC visual novel about dating pigeons

You play as the lone human enrolled at the St. Pigeonation's Institute, a prestigious high school catering to a diverse population of roughly human-sized sentient birds.

Your childhood best friend? A rock dove. Your maths teacher? A quail. The cool kid and resident school bad boy? A fantail pigeon who inexplicably also speaks in affected French on occasion.


Hatoful Boyfriend could have easily devolved into belabored bird jokes and puns for a cheap snicker, but instead opts for a surprisingly cohesive fiction and is all the more hilarious, heartwarming and disturbingly dark for it.


All of this is presented in the style of a visual novel as a parody of Japanese dating sim games.

That is to say, it offers a text-heavy branching storyline where the visuals mostly consist of a portrait of whichever character or characters you are talking to standing against some background scenery. It just so happens that in Hatoful Boyfriend, those character portraits are photographs of birds.

The thing is, it all actually kind of works.
Hatoful Boyfriend is a PC visual novel about dating pigeons


The absurd premise is treated with such absolute deadpan mundanity that it is hard not to be won over by its charm and sucked into the stories of your avian paramours.

And the writing, despite abundant typos, is quite good when it comes to fleshing out your feathered fellows into characters who are worthy of intrigue even if not always worthy of a young girl's affection.


The absurd premise is treated with such absolute deadpan mundanity that it is hard not to be won over by its charm and sucked into the stories of your avian paramours.


Hatoful Boyfriend could have easily devolved into belabored bird jokes and puns for a cheap snicker, but instead opts for a surprisingly cohesive fiction and is all the more hilarious, heartwarming and disturbingly dark for it.

Then things get weird. Yes, in a game about bird smooching, things had not yet gotten weird.

Hatoful Boyfriend is designed to be played multiple times, encouraging you to experiment with branching plot threads in order to see every bird's romantic conclusion.

Just as each subsequent playthrough starts to reach a Groundhog Day-like rhythm, Hatoful Boyfriend dives head first down a rabbit hole of plot that would make Hideo Kojima blush.
Hatoful Boyfriend is a PC visual novel about dating pigeons


And while the sharp turn is unexpected, it is a turn that the game completely earns every step of the way thanks to the balanced tone of its writing.

Sadly, for all of Hatoful Boyfriend's character charm, the game struggles on a technical level. The typo-laden script has already been mentioned, but bears repeating because of the word jumbles that made it past Mediatonic and Devolver Digital's editors.

The crucial epilogue scene, for lack of a better term, also sees your ability to save the game limited to certain rooms without any explanation. It is still possible to save the game outside of these rooms, but loading a save file there causes the game to start up without dialog boxes and making progress impossible. There are no save issues during the main romance plotlines, though.

Yes, Hatoful Boyfriend is a dating game with a bird gimmick, and that alone will be enough to keep many players at arm's length. But to pigeonhole your time at the St. Pigeonation's Institute as a mere gimmick would be a grave misjudgment of a game that is far more delightful and unexpected than even its bizarre premise would suggest.

reviewText:
I thought this game was a joke and so I bought it for the sh*ts and giggles, but instead I cried. A lot.
Anyway, here is what I think of the game so far.
Hatoful Boyfriend surprisingly has very well thought out story lines.
Artwork is pretty nice for the human versions of the birds and backgrounds.
Amazing character development.
Soundtrack is very enjoyable.I also very much loved the element of humor, mystery and romance in this game.
I know this is short and sweet, but it covers most of what the game has to offer.
Honestly, I have nothing negative to say about this game. It's beautiful.


I also realized that I'm attracted to birds now.
10/10 would go on date with a bird and seduce them again.

reviewText: Hidden under what looks to be a joke, this game is actually great. You take on the role of the only human student at St. Pigeonations. Why are you the only human? This might seem like a silly joke to further enhance the meme factor of the game. However, the story is much deeper than what you might at first think. The game has many unique characters, all with their own distinct personalities and stories. As of writing this, I've played through three characters. I enjoyed them all, however one in particular, Nageki, had me in tears by the end. This was defiently not what I was expecting when I first started up a pigeon dating sim.\n\nAll in all, if complex romance stories, or visual novels is something you enjoy, give this game a fair chance, despite what it might look like at first.

reviewText:
I, uh, I c-can explain! J-just give me a sec; it's not what it looks like! I got the game for t-the, um, story! Just listen, I'm going somewhere with this okay? *sigh* Okay, without further ado, I present to you...

LASTING IMPRESSIONS
Hatoful Boyfriend

GENRE
Dating Simulator/Visual Novel

STORY
In Hatoful Boyfriend you take the role of Hiyoko Tosaka, a human going to a prestigious highschool for birds. The school in question is St. Pigeonation’s, and it's known mostly for being the world's greatest gathering place for birds. You're a sophomore now, but you haven't done much to adjust to the atmosphere of Pigeonation's just yet. You're not entirely lost though, as you also have one of the several woo-able birds with you, your hardworking best friend Ryouta Kawara. Along with him you can also bond with narcoleptic math teacher Nanaki Kazuaki, bashful aristocrat Sakuya Le Bel Shirogane, distant bookworm Fujishiro Nageki, suave ladies' man Sakazaki Yuuya, enigmatic doctor Iwamine Shuu, and hyperactive track star Okosan. With so much romance in the air, it's hard to believe the school holds so many dark secrets...

GAMEPLAY
Ever read a book online? It's like that except every once in a while the books asks which choice you want to make. The choices you make will determine which bird you end up with, along with which ending you get for them. [Provided you don't get indesicive and go the way of the dodo, of course.] Each day you will be asked which class you want to take; this decides which trait will be leveled for that day. As previously mentioned, this will affect which ending you get for your desired bird.

VISUALS
Not much to say. It's pictures of birds with various backgrounds. The backgrounds look very nice, and there's quite a large amount of them. You also get a little end card pictures for your gallery after the end of each route. They're gosh darned cute.

SOUNDTRACK
The soundtrack is a delightful mix of royalty-free, classics, and original [I think?] tracks. All of them fit perfectly with any of the situations at hand. [Except maybe when Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy plays, that's always just plain silly.] There's many tracks from Kevin MacLoed and SENTIVE; the sexy, suave Dispersion Relation, Simply Blue, Daybreak [Personal favorite.], and tons of ones with gibberish for names. The collector's edition is worth is just for the beautiful OST.

SEQUELS [SPOILERS]
Hatoful Boyfriend is the quintessential example of an idea that I've had for a while now; some games should never get sequels. While it's obvious that a bad game shouldn't deserve a sequel; I'm of the opinion that if a game is GOOD enough it shouldn't HAVE a sequel. If a game does all that it wishes, if a game provides a fulfilling, complete experience; it would be insulting to continue where the game left off. You may be thinking 'How does a game about dating birds provide a fulfilling experience?' I'll tell you; it's because the entire dating sim portion of the game is a mere facade. Once you've completed all possible routes at least once, you have the option to unlock BBL; a grim narrative that reveals the lore behind this game's world, the motivations and sins of characters, and completes all story arcs. The dating sim part of Hatoful Boyfriend is there simply to set up characters so that you know who this story is centered around. You know how they act by then, what their situations are, and this only helps to greatly strengthen the story. It's a fantastic conclusion, and it's one that left me speechless. Which brings us back to sequels. As I've said, a sequel to this game woud be a downright insult; a direct sequel that is. A direct sequel would be insulting, as the game would have nowhere to go with the current story; all arcs are completed. However, an indirect sequel would be a very, very smart idea if done correctly. By merely taking the characters we know and love and putting them in a different kind of story; the game has somewhere to go. Oh, and it did go somwhere, as an indirect sequel exists. [Holiday Star is its name if you were wondering. Not yet on steam though.]

FINAL THOUGHTS
I dove this game. To say that this was a pheasant experience would be the understatement of the century. While at first glance, it may look like quite the bad egg, it's surely a narrative you'll never forget. I'm talon you, it's all here! Great soundtrack, amazing characters, bird puns; it's just a quail of a time! The price ain't nothin to go squawkin' about neither, no need to worry about some ludicrous bill. This is the defenition of the phrase 'more than meets the eye' and you'd have to be some hard boiled individual not to enjoy the humor at the least. I know I'm gushing, but I just can't recommend this enough! While you're at it, make sure to kill two birds with one stone and buy the collector's edition with it. The soundtrack alone makes it worth it. Alright, I've egged you on for far too much now, I'll sparrow you of any more. Hatoful Boyfriend has left a resounding lasting impression; it's not what the source material is, it's what you do with it that makes it a golden goose egg. You've got your ducks in a row MediaTonic, keep it up.

And now, in Japanese tradition, a haiku.
Hatoful Boyfriend,
A dating sim about birds.
I was not prepared.

reviewText:
A poem for a class, written in honor of this game.

Love is For the Birds

A ball of fluff perches
on my thin shoulder,
holding me tightly.
I am his prey and
I love his ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

He moves down my frame,
marking me all over with
his talons. Spreading my skin,
cutting me asunder.
Tenderly.

Are you sure?"
"Nevermore have I ever been."
"There's no going back."
"I'm no chicken."
"...Not another peep then."

Angelic wings descend lower
date:
fertilizing the richest of my soils.
Worms dart through the ground
Watered well by the rain.
The fallen angel blesses me.

A hawk-like cry from the Dove
signals his conquest
and he perches once again on my shoulder.
The bleeding heart's crest
Fills me.

"My angel."
"Are you ready to dive to the depths of hell
with me?"
"We go together into Gehenna
recommended:
Anghel.
My special somebirdie."

Anghel coos once again into my bosom.
How soft his plumage is on my chest.
His hard beak touches my fleshy
lips and we come together once more.
Taboo or not

reviewText:
It's 6:30 AM.I've been playing this for 3 hours straight.My eyes are soaked,my lips are salty and my fingers are shaking...

Let's start a story from it's beginning,shall we?

I bought this game without any thoughts about it,unless my girlfriend telling me it's freaking fun and epic.Even though it's orientated for females,I decided to get it and play.

My first run,I decided to date my math prof.Loved how he always felt asleep,and since my girlfriend watched me play,we were giving hilarious voices to everybirdie.I ended up managing to date him,and after this success I rushed back into the game.Next came Nageki,and there we both were shocked at the issue of this relationship.I ended up dating everyone,and especially loved Okosan's and Anghel's endings.Laughing at it's maximum,especially when you're with good company.

After a while,I couldn't stop playing.And one day...they gave me the choice to fullfil a promise.I looked at it wierd,and decided to not do it yet because I had endings to do still.

Finally,I decided to go in and fullfil those promises this night,on my own,without anyone else.I started the game and decided to date Ryouta just to see the difference.Even though there was some wierd messages from time to time...The run went as usual.Until one day...
/! SPOILERS FROM BAD BOY'S LOVE FROM NOW ON!/

Until the day Ryouta found my head in a box,while every other classes found parts of my body in others.It was a shock to see that this adventure got bloody.With extreme shock and thirsth of knownledge,I decided to keep going,and find the truth...

Everything went so fast,yet so slow.This dating sim has transformed into a dark thriller.Every seconds I was awaitting the Scarecrow to appear.Every seconds I was questionning things but never did I answer them.

After 3 hours in this run,I reached the end of Bad Boy's Love.I now know the truth behind this storyline. And here I am,tears to the eyes,salt to the lips,my mind questionning restless...

I was wrong about this game.When I first bought it,it looked funny.When I first played it,it was hilarious.When I played a lot,it grew tiresome but always so perfect.When I discovered the truth...It wasn't so funny anymore.I didn't know anymore who was evil,who was good,or who should be killed.I only know that this game is not any dating sim.

This game...There is no words.My tears are still flowing,even after the 20 minutes I spent writting this.I still ask myself questions,and answered few.

reviewText:
Most reviews promise something unique and they are right. There is a lot of enjoyable writing in this game" but to me it is worth neither the time nor the money needed to uncover it.

The setting is hilariously absurd and the graphics are quite minimalistic (hand drawn backgrounds with a total of about a dozen photos of birds for the foreground). I quickly got used to both. What really spoils the experience for me is the horrible interface. This game is basically a novel where you click through lots of dialogue. One would assume that it provides a pleasant interface for that. This is not so:
- The save function does not work when facing a decision - a natural point to save - and the saves seem to be broken at times.
- There is much overlap between subsequent playthroughs so it is very tempting to use the fast forward function. However
date:
that function does not stop when encountering those scarsely scattered bits of new dialogue. Also there is no rewind function so more often than not you miss some content. Why can't I just jump back and forth however I like? Even novels on paper have that feature.
- I really miss an overview of the characters with full name that is always accessible. The game uses first names or nicknames most of the time but occasionally a character is refered to by last name and you only ever see these in the initial introduction.
- Two of the endings have absolutely obscure trigger conditions and it took me a guide to get them.

Finally
recommended: be aware what you're getting for the price: After watching the trailer and looking at the screenshots on the store page and you have seen a good part of the visual content. Apart from that it is a couple of thousand lines of entertaining text in a flawed "engine"."

reviewText: Hatoful Boyfriend is a game where you go to bird school, which is for birds (and you, a human), and you date a bunch of different pigeons (or quails, or even a java sparrow) over a series of eight different routes. The game is relatively short in this aspect! I was surprised by how quickly I was getting through each route--even with fourteen endings to get (some sweet, some sad, some downright horrifying), the game itself feels surprisingly short.\n\nHowever, this is likely because completing specific routes unlocks the other half" of the game
date: as such--a more straight-up visual novel that reveals the secrets behind St. PigeoNation's (the school that you attend) and exemplifies some pretty excellent worldbuilding for what
hoursPlayed: appears to be a game about dating birds. It also delves further into the backgrounds of each of the main characters and will emotionally destroy you.\n\nThe game has a few typos and questionably built sentences
voteText: but it's overall an enjoyable playing experience. The background art is pretty nice to look at and some of the music is so great I sort of regret not buying the collector's edition to get the soundtrack.\n\n10/10

reviewText:
Hatoful Boyfriend
So my friend and I bought this game to have some cheeky giggles. And cheeky giggles were made. I aimed for Sakuya first, as did my friend. I succeeded, he died. It was good.

When I got this game, I read the reviews.
People said it got deep.
I was like psh, nothing I cannot handle.

I played through the first story.
Some parts actually got me. I was like wow, this is deep.
Ryouta's mother's death, Nageki's backstory, definitely hit harder
The game however, had a few laughs here and there and certainly did not look like it would be deep.

However, there is a second story, a much longer story.
This was a surprising turn on what the game looks to be.

The story was very interesting, very well constructed.
It was especially refreshing being able to play as another character, albeit not being able to choose.

The length was great.
The content was not only interesting, but deep and immersive.

I don't entirely agree with the price, however I got this game whilst on sale, which was a great price.

Regardless, I would definitely recommend this game to everyone, friends, family and random strangers. Even birds.
the doctor is mine

reviewText:
This is the funniest VN on Steam right now. It features lots of funny little bird puns + a colorful cast of characters.

It's a bit lacking as far as options and skip features go but each route is somewhat short so it's not really a major issue.

I encounted 2 small issues over the course of 2 hours. The game would get stuck when you load a game right after viewing the gallery. Loading a game in the middle of playing a route also does not update the date immediately. It fixes itself upon reaching the next day.

That was a weirdly entertaining VN. I'd give it a 4/5 for the bird theme combined with being vanilla (not to mention a good and awkward long route mixed with completing the game). If you like VNs that have a good sense of humor, I definitely suggest that you try Hatoful BF.

Though this game is quite serious, especially it's full ending, there are some funny jokes, and birdy" versions of words make me smile too. ^.^

reviewText:
Honestly, I didn't know what to expect when I went into this game.

I thought I was going to get a few laughs out of a ridiculous game.  I didn't really expect there to be much substance.

I have 100% completion on the game now, and let's just say... I literally cried.  The laughs and ridiculousness is there, but there is just so much more than that.  The story is riveting, and the writing is excellent.  You unexpectedly end up caring about the characters.  The choices you make feel like they actually make an impact in the storyline.  This is the first visual novel I have experienced on the PC, and I have zero regrets.  I am looking forward to playing the sequel soon.

reviewText:
♥♥♥♥ Her Right In The Cloaca - An Official Waffle King Review
~Find more here.[www.nonm.co.uk]

Everyone just wants to find love in this wild, crazy world of ours. Everyone just needs a shoulder to lean on, or an open ear to whisper their darkest secrets to. That's all anyone really wants. Even the ones that don't seem like they want love, they're the ones that need it the most.


Some people find love in family, or camaraderie. Some people find it in romance, or art. Some might find it at the bottom of a family-size bag of Cheetos while they jack off to pictures of girls with tails. Hey, everyone has their thing. Everyone is entitled to their own form of love. Unless they're humping their dog or their child, in which case it's illegal and they can find love in a prison shower.


People can find love everywhere and anywhere. Life finds a way. Even if you must go beyond your comfort zone. Beyond your race, your culture, and your people. Love knows no limits. Not even the sky. Because who wouldn't ♥♥♥♥ a bird?


I know I sure would. And if you don't think you're up to it, you haven't played this masterpiece yet. This isn't just a game. It's a journey. A life-changing experience. Prepare to have your eyes opened to the truth.


Hatoful Boyfriend actually falls under the category of visual novel, as it's a Japanese otome game. Otome is Japanese for sausage fest. You're playing a girl getting aggressively humped by every guy in the immediate vicinity. Which, in this case, are all birds. And you get to make the exciting choices that will determine not only who's eggs you'll be laying, but the fate of the world as we know it.


Hatoful Boyfriend was originally developed for the PC in 2011, later seeing multiple rereleases and upgrades before getting an HD remaster that released on Steam, PS4, and PS Vita.


Hatoful Boyfriend is, simply by existing, worth checking out. No where else can you experience the excitement of being the only human girl at an all-birds high school. It's the only of its kind, and simply the premise itself should warrant at least a single playthrough.


Not only is it relevant simply because of its premise, but it also works rather well simply on its premise alone. If you're picking it up simply because LOOK
date: BIRDS" you'll get exactly what you're looking for. It's wacky
hoursPlayed:
kooky bird fun. Good stuff.

voteText: a surprising amount of depth is layered. Spoiler alert

reviewText:
This game is cute, awkward, funny and dark.

It's one of those rare pieces of media that knows how to make fun of itself and embrace it's weirdness. Sure you might laugh at the concept of dating birds but that's only a cover or a proulouge to the true story undernieth the surface. You play as the only human in a school of birds so you might as well enjoy yourself while you're still alive.

I say if you want something different and are tired of normal dating sims and visual novels that you might like this game and laugh all along the way, but prepare for some dark topics and some heavy-handed emotional bits.

I think everybirdie should play this game at least once.

I give it 4 puddings out of 5

reviewText: Hatoful Boyfriend is a visual novel about birds. It is actually a parody of visual novels, with the classic character archetypes you'd expect in a school setting in an anime/visual novel: the childhood friend, the snob rich guy, the athletic guy...\nWhat differentiates it from other visual novels is, of course, the fact that these characters are all birds. That makes many normal situations inherently hilarious. However, do not dismiss it as just a comedy game. Beneath all the haha
date: birds" is a strangely compelling and engrossing story. There's a surprising attention to detail
recommended: from the random bird facts it throws out sometimes to the well-thought-out world full of interesting characters.\nI have few complaints about the game
hoursPlayed: but the main one would be the lack of an "auto-skip only seen text" option. To get all the endings you need to replay the game multiple times
voteText: which is immensely helped by the auto-skip button. However
helpfulPercent: the auto-skip will also happily skip over unseen content if you let it be. That can lead to missing certain scenes.\nStill

I have seen only ONE review on metacritic from which the writer had played the entire game. This is a perfect example of why video game journalism sucks a giant...C-O-C-K

This game is a 10/10, it is not a meme game, it is hilairous, if it is on your wishlist go ahead and get it and please for your own good go out of your way to avoid spoiling the plot.

reviewText:
My previous review seriously didn't give this game the credit where it was due. This game is seriously by far one of the most rollercoaster-y experiences I've ever had.

I'll admit, I bought this game because I thought it was a joke of a game; you start off by dating a menagerie of birds, all with differing personalities and different endings. Some are pure humor, others are tinged with sadness, and still others will make you question what the hell you just played (and even then, there's two ways you could go with this). I had some knowledge of the backstory beforehand, but I wasn't prepared for what came next.

The endgame takes the main game's rollercoaster of feels and turns it up to 11. Once a happy, satirical dating simulator, the game shifts to a murder mystery with one simple stroke. Over three hours worth of dialogue to digest, and over three hours of sheer emotional WTF; springboarding from utter despair to stifling a giggle at Okosan's antics is a bit jarring, but the game pulls it off rather well.

And the true ending?
If people take this review seriously and get the game, I just gotta say that it is by far one of the most touching endings I've experienced.

If nothing else, this game should be played JUST because of the endgame. The main game is a comedic and incredibly well-constructed setup to a tragic, emotionally charged ending that's satisfying in its own way. I completely, 100 percent recommend Hatoful Boyfriend as a game that everyone should experience in their life, as soon as possible.

reviewText:
Let's be honest: we all buy Hatoful Boyfriend for the sheer absurdity of what is, at its core, a visual novel pigeon dating game. And, on its surface at least, Hatoful Boyfriend is a shallow dating sim where the human main character is enrolled at St. PigeoNation's, a school for pigeons. She takes classes, she goes to festivals, and she romances and falls in love with various species of birds. However, Hatoful Boyfriend's stereotypical high school romance exterior is only an entertaining and light-hearted charade that covers up a plot full of politics, intrigue, mystery, and sorrow.

The first half of Hatoful Boyfriend is quirky and humorous, filled with various pop culture jokes and absurd situations. Players find themselves romancing one of several standard character archetypes: the childhood best friend, the lazy professor, the haughty aristocrat, the womanizing jock, the bullied library nerd, and so on. The scenarios are cute and heart-warming, with each character having their own separate little storyline. Every short playthrough of the game—which frequently take under an hour even if you read all of the text—ends with a primarily sappy romantic ending.

As players go through multiple playthroughs of Hatoful Boyfriend, however, a more insidious underlying plot is slowly revealed. Every romantic plot line will unveil more pieces of St. PigeoNation's dark history and the tragic cast of characters that attend classes there. These pieces on their own add spice to an otherwise bland dating sim that seems to cash in on its unique and somewhat ridiculous premise of a human girl dating pigeons. And, if one were to stop playing Hatoful Boyfriend after only a couple of playthroughs, that would be the feeling that one would be left with: Hatoful Boyfriend is an amusing dating game to spend an afternoon on, but nothing remarkable.

However, players that choose to stop playing Hatoful Boyfriend after only a few short playthroughs are missing out on the part of Hatoful Boyfriend that makes it an excellent game. If the first thirteen playthroughs of Hatoful Boyfriend are an amusing way to pass an afternoon, then the last playthrough is a gut-wrenching ride through a twisting plot that ties together everything the player has done up to that point. The short of it is this: this isn't just a game that you should play, it's a game that you should strive to complete 100% of the way.

reviewText:
Who wants to date pigeons?

Hatoful Boyfriend feels like a parody of your usual visual novels with pigeons obviously replacing human characters, and while it remains light and somehow making fun of itself most of the time, it can, at times, go a bit deeper than that.

It's probably not exactly going to emotionally break you down (except for that one route, yes), but yeah - I suppose the backstory is there and it's up to you whether you can immerse yourself enough to feel the birds and their lives.

In terms of how it plays, it remains a visual novel at heart, meaning you've got a bunch of routes and if you want to experience them all, it's going to involve loads of clicking, skipping, reading all the dialogues you've already seen many times, and so on. Therefore, I haven't got through all of the endings because it felt unnecessary grindy and repetitive. That's probably just me though, and if you like visual novels, this could be a nice, rather unusual one for your collection.

Also, you've got to love the pigeons' eyes.

reviewText:
This game. This is the game that got me started on visual novels. It is one of the best.
There are very few words that can describe this game, to be honest. On the outside, it looks like just a game about dating pigeons - a weird concept, to be sure, but hey, we're not judging.
Once you start to play the game, things get different. Hatoful Boyfriend is a story-rich, emotional game where you just happen to date pigeons. The character development is deep, the storylines that are behind each love interest are engaging, and more than once I have found myself sobbing because pigeons.
If you're a fan of visual novels and want to try something unique, this would be the game to try.

reviewText:
This game isn't entirely bad, but I don't think it's worth the money.

On the plus side:
The game is unique.
The secret ending that you can unlock is fairly interesting.On the minus side:
The writing, especially for the non-secret parts of the game, is quite poor and does little or nothing to attach you to the characters, and the jokes are rarely funny. The decisions you get to make are not all that interesting.
Only a minority of the text is different between the various non-secret paths. The majority is exactly the same, so you end up seeing the same text repeatedly.
The UI lacks the features one would expect from a game in this genre, and generally seems a bit shoddy. You can't save at decision points. There's no way to easily skip over the text you've already seen to get to the new stuff, which is especially egregious given how much duplication there is between paths. (You can fast-forward, but it skips right over the new text too.) And there's no way to review the dialogue if you accidentally miss a line.
There are some bugs. At one point, the game became unresponsive to input and I had to kill it, losing my progress since the last save. At another point, my saved game became corrupted and I had to start over. These were rare enough that they weren't really a problem, but they happened. Just save sometimes and use more than one slot.
The secret path - which is really the only reason to get this game - has effectively no interactivity. It's just an exercise in tapping the space bar and reading text for an hour. That said, it's at least fairly interesting text.The non-secret paths are short and the game as a whole will probably take about 7-10 hours if you have the patience to go through it all.

As somebody else said, it seems like the whole rest of the game is just a setup for the secret ending. It was something of a slog to get to that secret ending, but I did enjoy it once I got there. But I can't recommend this game at full price. You're basically paying for several hours of banal play" in order to get the reward of reading a non-interactive but fairly interesting short story. For the money you can buy much better full-length books
date: and there are plenty of fascinating short stories to read online for free. But if you really want to read a short story about anthropomorphic pigeons
recommended: Hatoful Boyfriend might be for you."

reviewText:
If you've enjoyed games like the Tokimeki Memorial or the Princess Maker series, give this one a try! If you have never touched any of the genre or are doubtful to try, let me give you a piece of advise. You can't really say this game has a high replayability value, but rather the replayability is the game! Gathering all the ends is just the way you go through an intro to all the characters, just to have the real story (BBL ending) unfold upon you, so don't trash it after the first try: if you plan to get to the credits and uninstall the game, don't even bother buying it. If you plan to actually read the dialogs... congratulations! You're gonna love it :D

Pros:
- fresh new approach
- awesome RP value!
- nice music
- hilarious gags
- skip button for all those known bits

Cons:
- stats values in this game have virtually no effect
- main stories are rather short and dull compared to similar games
- your input is rather limited so endings are rather easy to access, makes it too linear

reviewText:
I bought it so I could play a goofy game about dating pigeons and making excessive bird puns. I got that along with a nice dose of emotional trauma and a crippling case of the feels. I am ruined.

10/10

It's cute and clever but also has a great cast of characters and a suprisingly dark backstory which you find out over the course of several playthroughs. As you get enough endings a full, much longer addition to the story is unlocked, taking it from a cute story about what beans to buy your date to a full-on political murder mystery.

However weird you think the game is, I can promise that it's much, much weirder. And I love it.

reviewText:
I never expected my first game review to be about dating pigeons, nonetheless,

My brother bought this for me as a joke, which, it was made for April Fools day (not very suprising).
I began playing a few days later, closed it out after a few lines of dialogue. I went back to it a few days later and began actually dating the birds.
At first, I made jokes, but a few routes in, I, a bit disturbingly so, was enchanted by this weird little game. I really enjoyed the characters and their quirks, and was actually into the story and how everything played out. (I was a bit annoyed at the loose ends on some storylines.)
Then it came to the Bad Boys Love storyline (which, I wanted to do last, but not following guides I believed it to be Anghel's storyline (due to his options showed up around the same time)). This one went from cute bird dating sim to psychological horror/murder mystery quickly . This is when I started to get into it more and have a much stronger connection to the characters. Without spoiling, this route is what left such a positive impression on me, because it built on previous routes and tied up things that were not yet mentioned. After finishing that route (and epilogue) , I was restless because I just wanted more.

Now, I'm in a game slump, not wanting to play other games, waiting for the sequel, Holiday Star to be released.
Now my computer background is pigeons.
10/10

reviewText:
Here is a game as joyous and painful, as mysterious and memorable, as high school itself.
Hatoful Boyfriend captures the longing of the lonely, the brute insult of bigotry, and the wonder of even the most simplistic actions making the world feel right again in post-apocalyptic dystopian future. Compassionate, dramatic, this is writing that always knows when to take a moment for humor AND pathos. Let the deep and highly metaphoric story sink in over multiple playthroughs or you will be missing out on some of the best divergent storytelling of the generation.

As you click through interaction after interaction just know that others are out there are taking time to do the same. Slowly begin to realize that some people can be trusted. It was people that made this game, after all, people finally aware of the  consumer fatigue of space marines and dragons. You may never fully rehabilitate into a properly functioning member of human society by their standards but you understand, just as I understand, that it is people that we do NOT understand. Remember, birds can be trusted, birds always come back. Some people are meant to be with people, and others, like us, are just different. We may not have the shiniest of neck feathers and our ultimate failing is to be aware that we are not aware. But we have finally found somewhere we can live in peace.

Let us never forget the healing power of columbidae society but let us always try to remember to wash our berries before we eat them. Our digestive and respiratory systems may be different but blood is pumped into the heart from the body through the veins, the blood then enters the right atrium, then gets transported through the right ventricle and then is moved to into the lungs and oxygenated just the same.

In some things they shame us

reviewText:
This game isn't even a dating sim.  It's not some joke game about screwing birds.  It's not even a parody of dating sims.

This game actually just has the best story in a game since To The Moon.  At a first glance it's just a joke of a game, but the simplistic outlines lures you into getting to know the characters.  Then once you've begun to understand them, sudenly this option shows up that wasn't there before.

Next thing you know you're thrown into a heart wrenching story about the conflict of this crazy world the game takes place in.  You learn more about how these characters backstories were intertwined, and it helps you determine the fate of humanity to come.

Don't take this as some sarcastic review making a big deal out of some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.  This is an honest review about a game that I honestly love.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game may seem just a bird date simulator made just to provoke intense laughs, but it isn't. It's true that Hatoful Boyfriend provides a lot of funny, silly and even non-sense jokes but that's just the tip of the iceberg.

Actually, the game is a post apocalyptic story full of emotional traps. It includes 15 alternative endings and a true one. You can only play the true one after playing most of the others, but I suggest that you finish every other ending before tryin' the true one.

As the stories progress and you accomplish different endings, you'll learn a bit more about different characters. Their stories, their backgrounds, their aspirations and their wounds... They'll look just like real people and you'll start to love them. Bit by bit, the details of each bird story will form the background scenario for the true ending that's completely thrilling, gorgeous and unexpected. Get ready to shed a lot of tears.

I recomend this masterpiece to every Visual Novel fan. Believe me or not, this game is much more than it looks like.

reviewText:
Look man. Look. I just wanted to date some birds.
Seems weird, right? Well. I guess it is. But I was curious! Who could blame me! A dating sim? With birds? I'm no bird fanatic but it caught my interest.
And what I believed to be an innocent woo-ing (Or coo-ing, rather) pidgeon dating sim ended up a rollercoaster of emotional pain and deep, story-rich stress.

It began cute. Interesting. I live in a cave, a human girl. No parents. At most my closest friend is a kind rock-dove. Nice.
I persued birds far and wide. It was fun, at first. A cute, but sad ending. Endings that gave me a little giggle. Sometimes things seemed a little off, but isn't that the fun?

Oh, no, no it is not.

The choice is yours. Woo the birds. Befriend them. Learn their lives and histories, fall for their tales, tails, and quirks- but at a high emotional price
Or fly, far, far away.

Pros: Highly reccomended due to rich chaotic story and fun visuals.

Cons: I did not get to bang a bird.

reviewText:
I first bought this game when it first came out (Sept 2014), on sale, as a gag gift for my friend. I didn't understand why it was $10 for a dating game about birds, so I never bothered with it at full price. Me and some friends had some laughs going through one of the endings and it wasn't touched much since.

Fast Forward to the 2015 Summer Sale.

I bought 3 copies of Hatoful Boyfriend - again, on a huge sale. I'm the cheap friend - and gave two of the copies to friends, and saved one for myself to play for some small laughs. Get an ending or two, waste some time. But as I got more endings, I learned more and more about the world I was thrown into, and just how intriguing it was. And I learned more and more about the characters I'm around, and how everything fits together more than one would find in a simple dating simulator - human or otherwise.

Three and a half hours later:

I have gone through eight different endings. I have nearly cried twice, and completely ragequit once. I have been piecing the world together and it is an outstanding place. I have come to understand just why it is worth its full pricetag, and feel dirty having only paid a cut price for this.

In short, Hatoful Boyfriend is a top contender to being one of my favorite games ever. It deserves the chance to being yours too.

reviewText: At first glance, Hatoful Boyfriend may appear to be a parody of the visual novel dating sim games which have gained popularity recently.  And upon completing your first playthrough and finding a pigeon to be your soulmate, this would be an entirely accurate assumption to make.  However, the real depth of this game surfaces with each continual playthrough.  Something far more sinister is happening at St. Pigeonation's.  You will eventually find out the answer to almost any question you may have had when you first heard of the game.  Why is everyone a bird?  Why are you a human?  Who is the Hatoful Boyfriend?  The path to this knowledge will take a lot of perseverance, but you will be surprised by the outcome.

reviewText:
This isn't just a pigeon dating sim, there is a lot to this visual novel with plenty of choices and deep storylines. I may have gotten a little too emotionally invested in a few of the storylines and cried on more than one occasion.

For those wondering about the achievements, they're fairly easy to get, and the game has a skip button which is helpful if you find yourself selecting similar responses and remembering how the story went (though do be careful because it's a fast skip and you might miss something).

The extra ending that you get is worthwhile reading through, with a run time of around 2 - 3 hours depending on your reading speed.

reviewText:
First and foremost for those that fail to read the information above this is a visual novel. That means the majority of the content is reading. If you dislike reading turn back now.

Alright. For those of you still here yes this game is satire, but it can also take itself quite seriously. While playing this you have the amusing routes(which can overlap), the tear-jerking routes(which can overlap), the childhood friend route, the jerkwad routes, the senpai route, the sensei route, and the reformed thug/female route. Additionally there's the secret plot-heavy route that will not be spoken of for the sake of spoilers. The gameplay is much like you'd expect from a visual novel. Make a few choices. If you select the correct ones and have the proper stats congrats. You just landed yourself a good ending. Speaking of stats they aren't used as much as the other games of the same read-and-select format. An amusing game at the core for the most part.

Now what this rerelease was mainly supposed to fix was the engine. You see the previous engine back before the steam version was riddled with bugs and made playing it rather difficult. While this engine does run much more smoothly than Famous Writer did it does, in fact, have some bugs too. There have been reports of freezing on a white screen during the loading process before getting to the menu, crashing when loading human portraits, and likely more that have yet to be reported. Thankfully these aren't as numerous as the previous iteration. Still annoying, but some have reported fixing it by restarting the game. As per the others... Well this is a custom engine. Perhaps there will be patches in the future to fix the problems.

As per double the original price... Moa used a lot of open sourse content to make the game as cheap as possible at first, and this remake gave the game its own look background-wise as well as replacing that outdated freeware engine. The music is the same and the birds are higher resolution, but more or less the same. That said some of the birds are higher resolution than the other birds.

All in all I still do recommend it since it is less likely to backfire on you than the original and does provide a good deal of amusement.

Edit: It slipped my mind earlier, but the collector's edition does hold true on its claim. The original game is included if you feel like owning both renditions.

reviewText:
Got the game expecting a hilarious twist on the silly visual novels that I enjoy reading. The first stories that you read through where you pursue a relationship with each of the birds is pretty well what I expected.

Finish all of the main stories; some hilarious, some a bit surpising, some so outragously punny that I had to hold my breath, but all enjoyable.
Enter stage left, abruptly: The ACTUAL, ACTUAL real story of the game that ends up being incredibly deep, rather mysterious, with lots of soul searching and some truly soul crushing moments. Just.. God..  One of the best stories I have read in several years and I read a lot.

It takes time to get over the fact that everyone is a bird of some sort but by the time you've finished the first otome" style stories you've pretty well accepted the madness completely and you only see the characters rather than the feathers. Which was clearly done by design to crush you even further when the real story plays.  I highly recommend getting this and going through it. Look up a guide if you need it to get through the first part of the game but when you start to "Fulfill the Promise" drop them like a bad habit and just experience it. Because it is an experience."

reviewText:
Don't let this game's appearance fool you:
After playing through a handful of routes, you will unlock the true story of this game
(although it is highly recommended to have played all the other existing routes beforehand, to unlock the full ending and have a better sense of the characters).
Said route is way darker and connects everything you've learned about the characters, while using some narrative horror elements as well.
Unlike the other routes it also takes multiple hours to complete.

All in all, this game left me traumatized and I'll never be able to look at birds the same way again.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Hatoful Boyfriend is truly incredible, and for a number of reasons. Not only because the different routes and stories tie together in a far more intricate way than I ever expected. Not because even the parts you think might be boring are surprisingly heartfelt. Not even because it, a visual novel about dating photorealistic birds in an anime school, has brought me closer to tears than nearly any other game.

No, this game is really amazing because it's somehow managed to trick 99% of the people who have heard of it as to what it actually contains. Even people who have played it are often unaware of the full depth of its contents. You go into it expecting a light and silly parody game, and that is what it delivers, for a while. But once you begin to unravel what else lies within...

Hohoho, well... I wouldn't want to ruin the surprise, now, would I?
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
While it met my expectations as a parody of the dating sim genre with silly bird humor, it far exceeded my expectations with the depth of the plot. I was very surprised by the change in direction with the BBL ending but not in a bad way.

In the BBL ending, your choices have no consequences or really any effect on the story. This switches it from a dating sim to a visual novel experience. After spending x number of hours completing the dating sim endings, I enjoyed seeing the amount of thought put into each of the characters and their backstories. Even though some things weren't explained or expanded upon, I found it to be a satisfying conclusion.

Okosan forever! <3

reviewText:
I'm not a fan of sims but I do love a good story in any form. Definitely a lot of replayability due to each story path opening up more of the overarching plot that goes above bird romance. Seems silly on the surface but is pretty heartfelt once you give it a chance.

And to all my guild members reading this and asked about it, no, there aren't any graphic scenes.

Would recommend this to everybirdie.

Edit: Okay, so I got to the final chapter.. All I can say is that this game escalated quickly and probably shouldn't be played while alone in the dark.
