reviewText:
This game is one of those rare few that seems like its one thing, and then it ends up being something much, MUCH, greater than expected. Going into it you might think its just a weird Japanese visual novel about dating birds. And, well, it sort of is. But what you wouldn't know without playing it is just how much more there is to this game.

The vast amount of diversity speaks volumes of the effort put into making this game the experience that it is. Although it is classed as a dating sim, this is one of the few games that tackles many other genres, and actually does it well. Basically, each of the different characters' story lines you can follow are unique to one another. Each character has a very different personality and backstory, as well as their routes have their own uniqe themes and plots that other characters routes don't necessarily have a focus on. This is what makes this such a great game, because it makes you WANT to complete every route so you can learn the whole story, rather than making you feel like you have to suffer through several playthroughs of the same thing to get the end result. Each of the different characters stories are enjoyable and entertaing in their own unique way, be it a sweet romance, or a bone-chilling mystery, they are all very different.

Then of course, there is the secret true ending" story route

reviewText:
Hatoful boyfriend is a game one can never simply forget. True, it looks like a simple joke aimed towards visual novels and the like, however that is not the case. This game has enough to crush a player's heart through various ways but can also reward you with happiness on some routes. All the same, this game is more than meets the eye. The images and art used is high quality as standard, although a couple of birds do seem a bit blurry and pixelated. The English translation has been done well and I have only noticed a couple of minor errors (or what seem like errors) on the BBL ending. This should not deter you from getting this seemingly innocent game and playing it yourself, as the gameplay is superb and of a high quality overall.
It was enough to make me cry a few times, and for my heart to swell quite a lot especially for one particular character (out of sadness).
Final rating - 9/10
This game is a lot less of a joke than the store page makes it out, so keep that in mind.

reviewText:
Nobody should be leaving a review until they've unlocked the BBL/Hateful Boyfriend storyline. That is the point where this game becomes something else entirely and you will have your mind blown.

You get lured in thinking it's all fun and games laughing at a ridiculous pigeon dating game, then find yourself boggling at hints that not all is as it seems as you court the different birds. You may even be moved to tears or scared s***less during your very first playthrough if you choose one of a few birds, a sharp wake-up call that this game is something more. By the second or third time you restart the game and court someone else, you begin to have your belief entirely suspended and forget that the characters aren't human. When you unlock BBL, set aside a good 3-4 hours to fully take in the other side of the game. You will not be able to look away.

Genuinely one of my favorite games. More masterfully written and emotive than any story Hollywood has put out lately. 10/10

reviewText:
The game is pretty entertaining because the writing is good and the idea of dating pigeons is funny.  The characters are great, all with distinct personalities, including the main character.  Unlike some other dating sims, it doesn't branch off into a separate route for each character you date --instead, the new stuff for each character is interspersed between scenes common to each character... expect to be hitting the skip button a lot.  The amount of new content for each character is pretty good, though.

The real meat of the game is when you unlock the final route after completing all the other routes.  To put this in perspective, there are 15 endings (not counting an epilogue).  I read all of the dialogue out loud with my friend, using the skip button for dialogue we already saw before.  It took 10 hours to do the 14 normal routes and 6 hours to do the final route alone-- that's how big the difference is.  So make sure you do the final route, since it's a huge amount of the game and it really ties everything together well.

Where the game fell short for me was in the implementation.  There were a number of annoying technical aspects that really detracted from the game.  One was the skip button, which sometimes failed to skip past old dialogue and would also skip past new dialogue.  Another big one was the save games, which do not work if you have the game installed somewhere other than your C drive-- a real annoyance with the really long final route.  And then there were just some small annoyances like unnecessary extra clicks (such as having to click twice before every choice), the slow speed of the scene transitions, and a ton of typos... which were actually kind of entertaining, but still.

Even so, the game is worth playing.  It might not be the most polished VN you'll ever play, but it has some solid writing and is just a really fun experience.

reviewText:
Hatoful boyfriend is a game one can never simply forget. True, it looks like a simple joke aimed towards visual novels and the like, however that is not the case. This game has enough to crush a player's heart through various ways but can also reward you with happiness on some routes. All the same, this game is more than meets the eye. The images and art used is high quality as standard, although a couple of birds do seem a bit blurry and pixelated. The English translation has been done well and I have only noticed a couple of minor errors (or what seem like errors) on the BBL ending. This should not deter you from getting this seemingly innocent game and playing it yourself, as the gameplay is superb and of a high quality overall.
It was enough to make me cry a few times, and for my heart to swell quite a lot especially for one particular character (out of sadness).
Final rating - 9/10
This game is a lot less of a joke than the store page makes it out, so keep that in mind.

reviewText:
Hatoful Boyfriend is a short, parody visual novel with a branching storyline and multiple endings. It features a human girl in second year of high school attending a prestigious St. Pigeonation's Institute, which before would only have birds. As the only human in the school the protagonist attempts to find love among the winged animals, similar to dating sims.

At first I was very annoyed how shallow the game seemed. Days went too fast like you weren't attending the school or trying to socialize with the characters you were supposed to fall in love it. You couldn't get to know the characters much deeper and there weren't many choices for practically anything. And even if  it took me almost 10 hours to get all the endings, one storyline with one character doesn't last much longer than one hour so in that aspect I would call it a short game. I was annoyed because I thought HB had only received such a high fame status and a positive rating due to some YouTubers playing it. You know those games that just get famous because reasons and in reality there's not much meat in them? I was so sure Hatoful Boyfriend was one of them and so I started to feel resentment towards it.

That was until in my playthrough, the path I chose with the character I could relate the most, a sad plot twist happened. And it blew me away. I kept playing and thinking Wait a minute. This game is supposed to be goofy and funny with its pigeons and bird references. This can't happen. This can't be sad. What is going on!?" And as I kept going and choosing different storylines and different characters to romance
date: more and more twists and turns were thrown at me. So many twists that they could put M. Night Shyamalan to shame.\n\nAnd I started to realize everything was not so superficial as I thought it was. Presumably the creator first meant HB to be an April Fool's joke but as it started to gain attention she began to properly work on the game. And to quote her she wanted "to create something that seems ridiculous and crazy at first glance
recommended: but that once you look into the world
hoursPlayed: you would fall into the depth". This is what best describes Hatoful Boyfriend.\n\nAnd so it is unfortunate the best part of the game only comes after playing halfway through. It is a special kind of ending which you can only unlock after going through multiple other endings. This Bad Boys Love ending
voteText: as it is called
helpfulPercent: differs by being much more lengthy than the others (about the length of one storyline with one character if not even more) and having a different protagonist. From there on out the game changes from a comedic
votesHelpful: teenage school life to a full-on murder-mystery solving. That ending is what makes everything better by having many heartfelt and grim moments which can also make you like a character you didn't like before and vice versa. It was at that point when I started to enjoy myself.\n\nLikewise there are bits and pieces of the whole plot sprinkled all over which you can only find if you go through everything. Alone they won't make much sense but once you find everything and put the pieces together
votesTotal: things start to take shape. That student ID  card you found on the floor and handed to a teacher? You couldn't understand it at the time but in the next storyline you definitely would. Or the suspicious conversation between two individuals? The strange death of one gloomy student? Everything is linked somehow.\n\nOf course not everything is perfect in the paradise. There is a huge saving/loading bug
votesFunny: the latter one negatively affecting me. I could save but I couldn't load my saves (evidently rendering saving pointless) so every time I started a new game I would have to play it through in one sitting. And some people have had trouble saving their games. It baffles me glitches so bad have been since the release yet nothing has been done to fix them.\n\nSteam only allows you to either recommend or not recommend a game so I'm forced to pick one of them. I have very mixed feelings about Hatoful Boyfriend. In the end it surprised me in a good way but there are things which got in the way of me liking it too much. It is the first half which sets the whole game back for me. If it all had been something along the lines of the extended BBL ending with comedic reliefs in-between
commentsCount: I'm sure it would have been that much better. And though there is some deep content to find within
column16: you have to keep digging quite a while to find it. In order to witness the conversations you couldn't see before and unlock rest of the endings
column17: you have to repeat much of the gameplay you already went through. This repetitiveness is tiring and dull.\n\nIt isn't a bad game
column18:
but in my eyes it isn't so good to warrant a positive rating.

Pros:- Storylines are intertwined cleverly
- Numerous great plot twists
- Second half of the game (aka BBL ending)

Cons:- Save/load bug
- First half of the game (before BBL ending)
- Repetition of gameplay to get to good parts

Personal Rating: 3/5 - Mixed"

reviewText:
This isn't just a dating sim with birds - it's much, much more. It challenges the social standings of humans and their place in the world - the world that humans have altered themselves for the greater good, only to have their creations turn against them. It touches upon the existance of the supernatural, and the consequences of mingling with fate and the higher order. The juxtaposition between the birds and the humans is highlighted as you interact with key characters. You will have to face with and debate against (or for) political issues that will directly affect your well-being. The more you, a human, gets involved into these affairs, the more you unravel about the hidden mystery behind St. PigeoNation Institute of Littledove Hachiman City.

Would definitely recommend - you will not be disappointed.

reviewText: I bought this game out of sheer, burning curiosity thinking it was going to be a light-hearted, silly game about dating birds. I was in a state of turmoil - what had come over me? Was this some kind of mid-mid-life crisis? How far was I going to sink into depravity before finally snapping out of it and coming to my senses? I was embarrassed and didn't want to admit to even my closest friends that I was won over by this charming game.\n\nBut then I couldn't stop telling them about it. I wanted to tell the whole world what a twisted surprise Hatoful Boyfriend turned out to be. Yes, of course it's ridiculous, of course you can't take it TOO seriously, but it is also so much deeper than just a bird dating sim." It commanded all my attention and free time over the course of four days until I was finally able to finish it. I obviously can't say too much without spoiling it (as anyone who's played knows) but if you're going to set aside reservations for only one game in your life

reviewText: I bought this game out of sheer, burning curiosity thinking it was going to be a light-hearted, silly game about dating birds. I was in a state of turmoil - what had come over me? Was this some kind of mid-mid-life crisis? How far was I going to sink into depravity before finally snapping out of it and coming to my senses? I was embarrassed and didn't want to admit to even my closest friends that I was won over by this charming game.\n\nBut then I couldn't stop telling them about it. I wanted to tell the whole world what a twisted surprise Hatoful Boyfriend turned out to be. Yes, of course it's ridiculous, of course you can't take it TOO seriously, but it is also so much deeper than just a bird dating sim." It commanded all my attention and free time over the course of four days until I was finally able to finish it. I obviously can't say too much without spoiling it (as anyone who's played knows) but if you're going to set aside reservations for only one game in your life

reviewText: On the surface, this game seems completely stupid; something that you would buy only as a joke. After binge playing this game with all my free time for about 4 days, I can honestly say that this may be in my top 3 games for this year. This game actually has a serious story. One that you need to get all of the endings to put together and one that will make you step away from the keyboard after you're done and say What the hell just happened?" This game is amazing. I never once thought I would be attached to any of these characters but there were times when I legitimately almost teared up. This game is funny. It's sad. It's downright tragic. You are doing yourself a disservice by not picking up this game. And you are doing yourself a bigger disservice if you already have it
recommended: and dismissed it. As someone who has played quite few visual novel type games I can say without a shred of hesitation this is one of the best. 10/10
hoursPlayed: would attend St. PigeoNation's again."

reviewText:
I have a love-hate relationship with dating sims. I love almost everything about their writing, the nature of the narrative slowly unfolding non-linearly with each replay, and the exploration of character and testing the player's understanding of character.

I love also how it critically looks at various staples of love-interests in romance in a way that romance novels rarely do. We have more than just the standard alpha-male.

What I don't like about dating sims is that I have yet to find one which lets me just skip (not fast-forward - SKIP) scenes I've seen before and the sheer amount of grinding involved in stat building. Sometimes I want to do-away with stat-building completely and take a page out of Moacube's book where you have other types of decisions which advance plot define your character's character and stats".

Hatoful tries to make stat building more connected to plot by actually providing you with a unique scene along with each stat building time point. However
date: I still found the stat building unecessary. I also found the needing to romance a character in two different ways in order to unlock the epilogue really...arduously boring.\n\nThat said
recommended: Hatoful Boyfriend improves on a lot of other dating sim mechanics and really invests in taking the player's preconceptions of whimsy and istead offers a genuinely good science fiction story. There is a lot of depth in this game should you commit to seeking it and a lot of heart.\n\nI still await the day where we work towards dating sims that remove grinding
hoursPlayed: whether that's re-doing vast stretches of story to get to new scenes or improve (or do away with) the stat building. Sadly
voteText: Hatoful Boyfriend still suffers from both
helpfulPercent: though to a lesser extent than the average dating sim. This detracted from my experience. I still heartily recommend this game as amongst one of the top games you can play in its genre. (Seriously.)"

reviewText:
I can't believe I'm about to say this, but I believe Hatoful Boyfriend just might be one of the best games I have ever played. Please hear me out first before you call me crazy! (Warning: spoilers ahead) I believe you are supposed to follow the romances in the order of the achievement list to maximise the effect.

It starts out as what you'd expect: a simple dating sim where you can romance birds. But as you go along, the supernatural becomes more evident, with ghosts and weird pudding gods (???) and fallen angels and reincarnations and stuff. And then you get to the highlight of the game. The BBL ending. Whereas the 14 other endings took me about five to six hours to complete, I was staring at my screen for like three hours for this, and I couldn't stop no matter how much my eyes hurt. It's madness.

What started as a cute bird romance sim became some weird combination of horror and mystery, with a conspiracy that tied practically every single main character to each other in some way or other. The hints have been there all along, even in the normal" romance routes
date: but after playing this you'll understand everything
recommended: and your mind will be blown away.\n\nOn a sidenote
hoursPlayed: I wonder what kind of drugs the makers had to take to think of this kind of ♥♥♥♥.\n\n10/10 would rather play Hatoful Boyfriend BBL ending than watch/read Game of Thrones."

reviewText:
It's a pigeon dating sim. And it's everything you could ever want from one.

While highly self-aware of just how ridiculous it is, and embracing the sheer silliness of everything, there's a weird sort of sincerity that makes it less just a throwaway joke and more of an actively enjoyable running gag. Though the premise is pure comedy and much of the dialogue is humorous, it never gets tiresome and instead actually becomes quite intriguing as you dig deeper into the bizarre fantasy world of pudding-obsessed pigeons.

Also one of them is a serial killer. So there's that.

reviewText:
I started playing this game as a joke.  I expected a good deal of WTF, and got a lot more than I bargained for!  I've never played a dating simulation before (it's not really my thing), so I can't measure Hatoful Boyfriend against other similar games.  However, I will honestly say that I have enjoyed the stories that unfold.  (I'll admit, tears were shed!)

The music and sound effects are mostly cheesy.  I thought the premise of dating birds was random and humourous, but to my surprise, the game finds a way to make it plausible.  There's an interesting, hidden underlying story that gradually gets revealed as you play through different birds' stories and endings.

In summary, I didn't know what to expect from Hatoful Boyfriend, but it surprised and delighted me.  It's no masterpiece, but I enjoyed the time I spent playing it.

reviewText:
Sit down kids. Let me tell you the tale of my experience with Hatoful Boyfriend.

I bought this game during the Summer Sale of 2015 for around $2.50. The only real reason I did was because I'd told a friend of mine I would and I didn't really want to pay $10 for a game about dating pigeons. Anywho, after buying the game I started it up, figuring I'd play a route before my friend came to play it with me. I think I named myself Deez Nuts. Sometime in the beginning, before I began to romance a pigeon, I exited. I felt guilty for not waiting for my friend, though, so I quit.

Fastforward to a month or so later. I can't wait for this game anymore. No one else is using the computer and because my brothers are occupied with other things I've got the whole day to waste away on it. Nageki's route is the first I complete because he's a shota boy and he's tiny and quite.

[SPOILERS START HERE]
This was a mistake. There is much more to Nageki- he is not just a tiny quite shota boy. He is a tiny quite shota ghost. And after you fall in love he disappears, because you helped him remember why he died. The first of many tears were spilled here.

Figuring his route was the only one that invloved such an upsetting twist, I began to progress through the game. I wanted those achievments.

Next up was Sakuya. Not super depressing this time, which was good. So, Yuuya's next.

I made another mistake here. Lots of important plot was revealed in Yuuya's route, but honestly I can't remember it all.

I played Okosan's route after Yuuya's. Very silly. It was exactly what I had expected of the game.

Ryouta's route. Oh man, Ryouta's route. I liked this bird from day one. But of course, like all anime best friends, there's more to it. His mom is dying. He's working so hard to pay for her medical bills. So hard. And she ends up dying anyway. The ending is upsetting, but very sweet nonetheless.

Math teacher's is pretty average, if I remember right. I don't actually remember much about it, but I think we learn that his brother died long ago? I don't know.

Shuu's route was the worst of the main ones by far. It's as creepy as is to be expected, and then some. Of course, you die in both the ends, the true end being MUCH WORSE than the normal ending.

I say main endings because there are EVEN MORE LAYERS to this game.

After completing all the main routes, you unlock a special secret route called Bad Boys Love, also known as Hurtful Boyfriend" and/or "BBL". This route made me feel such intense distress. It is the reason I have 12 hours on this game. There were multiple times I had to stop and take a moment to compose myself in this route. It is REALLY that upsetting. The worst thing is I still feel it. I think about it when I fall asleep
hoursPlayed:
and I feel an emptiness in me that cannot be filled.

[SPOILERS END HERE]
I regret buying this game only because it has toyed with my emotions too much for it to be fixable. Years from now

reviewText:
Short Version / TL;DR
Hatoful Boyfriend is a fantastic dating sim. You might think the whole concept of a dating sim with birds as the characters a bit silly, but it has a story and characters that really pull you in. Plus, the extra storyline, Bad Boys Love AKA Hurtful Boyfriend, could be a short game of it's own.
Rating: Buy if you're interested in this kind of game, or if you want to try the genre out. If you're unsure, wait for a sale, you just might love it.

Long VersionMight include small spoilers!

Characters
The characters are extremely well designed, in general. In the beggining you'll be introduced to a relatively small number of characters, which may be hard to remember, due to their names, which are Japanese names like Sakuya or Yuuya, but after your first playthrough you should become confortable with remembering some of their names.
For me, most characters are interesting, with the exception of Ryouta, who isn't as interesting, due to being the more normal out of the group, and because I find his backstory depends too much on his mother.
Character Rating: 9/10

Story
The story is absolutely amazing. With various ending, you'll be entertained for various hours. The story largely depends on what route you take. For example, San's story is mostly comical, but Nageki's is mysterious and a bit saddening. I haven't played through all of Bad Boys Love, but from the great part I've seen until now, it's extremely mysterious and depressing, and, as stated before, could be a game on it's own.
Story Rating: 10/10

Graphics
The graphics are good for a game of this kind, the human counterparts are beautifully designed, and the backgrounds are generally well drawn. All I'd say bad about them is that the birds might not always be as high quality as the backgrounds, but don't come with expectations of AAA quality graphics.
Graphics: 8.5/10

Music/Sound
The game has music that almost alwyas fits the situation, and can vary from the depressing tunes played all over the game, to San's cheerful theme, to Hurtful Boyfriend's frightening songs.
Music/Sound: 9/10

Final Rating:
I think it's a must have for visual novel/dating sim fans. If you're unsure whether you'll like it or not, wait for it to go on sale, and pick it up then. Or offer it to a friend as a joke, and maybe he'll love it (like what hapenned to me!).

reviewText:
I have a love-hate relationship with dating sims. I love almost everything about their writing, the nature of the narrative slowly unfolding non-linearly with each replay, and the exploration of character and testing the player's understanding of character.

I love also how it critically looks at various staples of love-interests in romance in a way that romance novels rarely do. We have more than just the standard alpha-male.

What I don't like about dating sims is that I have yet to find one which lets me just skip (not fast-forward - SKIP) scenes I've seen before and the sheer amount of grinding involved in stat building. Sometimes I want to do-away with stat-building completely and take a page out of Moacube's book where you have other types of decisions which advance plot define your character's character and stats".

Hatoful tries to make stat building more connected to plot by actually providing you with a unique scene along with each stat building time point. However
date: I still found the stat building unecessary. I also found the needing to romance a character in two different ways in order to unlock the epilogue really...arduously boring.\n\nThat said
recommended: Hatoful Boyfriend improves on a lot of other dating sim mechanics and really invests in taking the player's preconceptions of whimsy and istead offers a genuinely good science fiction story. There is a lot of depth in this game should you commit to seeking it and a lot of heart.\n\nI still await the day where we work towards dating sims that remove grinding
hoursPlayed: whether that's re-doing vast stretches of story to get to new scenes or improve (or do away with) the stat building. Sadly
voteText: Hatoful Boyfriend still suffers from both
helpfulPercent: though to a lesser extent than the average dating sim. This detracted from my experience. I still heartily recommend this game as amongst one of the top games you can play in its genre. (Seriously.)"

reviewText:
The first VN I have played in my life, and one of the more enjoyable VNs I have experienced in my life as well (which isn't a lot mind you).

Hatoful Boyfriend is about dating birds, and over time, finding out the events that lead to a human girl attending a pigeon school and forming romantic relationships with them. Hatoful plays with its unique premise, leading the way for pigeon related antics and such. The comedy is great in the VN, the drama fits, and everything works out. The staff even managed to fit in a number of anime or japanese pop culture references into the show as well, which may or may not be your thing (it definitely was enjoyable for me).

The second part of the VN, is where a lot of the history of the setting is explained, and trades all of the comedy and silliness for drama. The drama is decent, the payoff is pretty meh, the story and background is pretty well done and fleshed out. The second part is also incredibly long, like hours long, just a warning.

Overall Hatoful Boyfriend is an enjoyable experience. Each route is quite special in its own way, and they each have a certain charm to them. Having to perfect this game didn't bother me at all, as I had fun playing it all the way through.

I don't even know how to grade this. I love visual novels but how can you critique a parody of bad visual novels? It's lacking a quick save feature and you can't scroll up to text previously read. I guess it's okay. Whatever.

reviewText:
This game is amazing. Admittedly, my experience with visual novels is a bit lacking (consisting mostly of Analogue: A Hate Story, Hate Plus, and various Twine games), but I have a feeling that Hatoful Boyfriend is probably not quite representative of a typical Japanese dating sim VN (and not just because of the birds).

I don't want to spoil too much of the story, but it frequently veers pretty far off the beaten path. Japanese High school dating sim VNs have never really appealed to me too much as a general concept, but this game is much, much more than just a dating sim. The stories are wildly varied depending on your choices and what ending you're going for. There is thankfully a fast-forward button to get right to different choices to see how they play out, as well as ample save slots for saving before important choices.

And I'd strongly recommend playing through every ending (don't be afraid to use a guide after your first playthrough). Each ending is interesting and varied on its own, but also because it unlocks a special epilogue story that's actually much longer than a normal playthrough. And the epilogue is definitely worth playing through - it gives a lot of background information on how the (evidently post-apocalyptic) society came about, and explains a lot of the backstories of the birds and the world you inhabit. It does drag on a bit near the end, but I'm really glad I played through to the end.

If you like visual novels you'll love this game. If you don't like visual novels you'll still love this game because it's hilarious and weird and delightful. It certainly delivers a silly tongue-in-cheek bird dating parody, but it's so much more than that. Buy it.

reviewText: Hatoful Boyfriend isn't just the hilarious pigeon dating sim you see on the surface. Radical political parties, genocide, experimentation, biological warfare, murder, pudding--just to name a few--are all themes you'll encounter in this game.\n\nYou are a human transfer student in a school specifically for birds. Unbeknownst to you, your mission is to woo every bird in the school, albeit one at a time in separate playthroughs. Each bird has different interests, personalities, and backstories, but the more you play, the more you'll realize that they're all intertwined, and that there's something terribly sinister going on at your school behind the scenes. Once you've seduced every bird and achieved every ending, you are rewarded with a chance to fulfill the promise
date:
and solve a mystery that will leave you on the edge of your seat for hours.

Hatoful Boyfriend is beyond deceptive in its marketing as a joke, and I hadn't expected that it would tell a wonderfully written story that would leave me in tears at its end.

--

My only gripe about Hatoful Boyfriend is the spotty save system, as so many others seem to have issues with, too. I would occasionally need to load a save only to find that it would load a background without characters, text, or interface, forcing me to Alt+F4 to leave the game. The save file was forever corrupted, and I would have to restart that particular storyline. The dating playthroughs are short enough to finish in single sittings, but the finale can take hours to finish. I would recommend playing the finale only if you know you have a lot of free time ahead of you, at least until the save issues are fixed. I will amend this review should they be resolved.

Oh, and the occasional typo or missing word, but that's not a big deal.

--

Have fun, everybirdie!

reviewText: By all means buy this game.  Just do it.  I thought it was a silly romance dating game with pigeons.  It is.  But it is also so much more.  I always keep close attention to little details and odds and ends throughout, but this game takes it to the top with the final BBL ending.  I don't want to give away too much, but each ending holds a significance for a later entry of the story, especially stuff you probably thought was a joke and laughed about.  Terrifying, upsetting, romantic, silly, and well-thought out, this game is probably one of my absolute favorites.  Don't hesitate to buy it, just do it (especially if it's on sale).   It's a thrill ride if you're willing to give it a shot

reviewText:
I was extremely excited to have a nice laugh and fall in love with a few birds, have a good life.

I was horribly, horribly misled.

Hatoful Boyfriend is many, many things, but an innocuous dating sim is NOT one of them.

Sure, there are the bird puns. And the crazy shenanigans of the birds and you being the only human girl in the school.

But there's so much more. I can't say much without spoiling anything, but I will let you know that I was left in a puddly mess of tears and wondering why I was crying over fictional birds. This game is nothing short of amazing. Don't let the concept fool you. This game will break you. This game will have you staring at your screen in shock and feeling emotions for pigeons that you would have never thought were possible. This game will emotionally destroy you.

10/10

reviewText: This is no ordinary pigeon dating simulator. Yes, you can flirt with and persue a bird of your choice, but it's so much more than that. Not only must you choose between Yuuya, the man-about-town and his smooth words, his half-brother Sakuya, the haughty aristocrat with a secret past, or any of the other mysterious and unusual birds at St. Pigeonation's... You must ford the confusing waters of an international conspiracy. Will you join the track team or the student council? Will you encounter the darkness beneath you all? Will you go to the fair with Ryouta, your friend and ally? Or will you take the arm of Shuu, the dastardly and intimidating physician? 10/10 GOTY

reviewText:
The game is not just about pigeons, there are many different kinds of birds with their own agendas!

If you are hoping for bird sex then you will be gravely disappointed, but if you are hoping for a very weird psychological thriller / murder mystery then you will be happy.

A good point in favour of this as a visual novel / 'dating sim' is that all the routes you can take are logical and it is not tedious to get full completion, even without using a walkthrough. Make use of the skip function in the upper right, but be careful with it...

reviewText: Excellent game, fantastic game - I did not know who I was before playing Hatoful Boyfriend.  I've always felt a strong kinship with birds of all kinds, and this game only expanded upon that.  I was thrust headfirst into the life of high school birds, each accompanied by their own unique personality!  All of my senses were titillated as I lived out my very own bird's entire social life through highscool, culminating in a life-lasting relationship with the bird matched to me via the game's algorithm!  Wow!  What an experience this game was, and I truly wish for more downloadable additions to this franchise.  This game has spawned my own quest to research more about bird social groups and explore more about bird psychology on my way towards developing my inner bird.  These topics fuel my passion for who, ultimately what, I am.  I am forever in debt to this game for the light that it has shown me.  I am humbled.\n\nYou will be given the opportunity to transform your birds into humans but you will ruin the experience and perpetuate the myth about the misunderstaing of bird cognitive abilities.

reviewText: A silly dating game where you date birds? Guess again. That is just the beginning. If you dig deeper to the game, you find well written and suspensful story that grabs you by your heart with a tight grip and makes you care about these birds. The story is very complex and I highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys anykind of visual novels or just a very good, well written story.  Just be open minded when going to this game; it's more than a dating game about birds. Believe me.\nBut it does require lots of reading the same dialogues again to get all the endings that lead to the very best part of the game. So beware that you will have to work a bit for the hidden gems that this game offers. But think it's a reward. For once completing everything in the game gives you something, not just achievements, but actually more story to dive into. Probably one of the best visual novels I have ever encountered.

reviewText: Birdie lovin' with birds. All jokes aside, this game is a very solid VN. Don't let the pigeons fool you, it's not simply a gimmick, the author honest to god loves birds and it really shows! When I played the original version a few years back, I initially was grinning like an idiot to sobbing uncontrollably and this game gave me feelings I never asked for or expected at all. It's definitely more than what it appears to be on the surface, so if you love visual novels or don't mind text heavy stuff I'd highly recommend this. Plus, proceeds do contribute to the purchase of toys and food for the real life version of some of these birds. You wouldn't want to leave Okosan hungry, would you?\n\nIf you've already played the game, this adds an Azami route and polishes up backgrounds and for me, the text was much easier on the eyes. If you haven't played before, prepare for a wild ride and an intense urge to hold hands with fluffy pigeons. It's worth every penny and if you love it as much as I do, look into the mini-sequel Holiday Star! (Or wait for it's HD Edition announcement.)

reviewText:
Hatoful Boyfriend appears on the surface to be some sort of joke, but it's actually a lot, and I mean *a lot* better than it has any right to be. It starts off as an otome-style dating sim/visual novel with cutout photographs of birds, primarily pigeons. It sounds like the most bizarre premise for a game ever, and for the first couple of playthroughs, it is. You'll laugh at the madness, the implausible scenarios (just how do pigeons use those desks from the classroom background, anyway?) and the goofy dialogue. You'll probably get Okosan's ending first, because it's just too absurd to resist. You'll treat the game as if the whole thing were some sort of silly parody.

But then ... something happens, and you acclimate yourself to the weird world of pigeon dating, and all the sudden the cast reveals itself as the well-developed, sympathetic, and strong characters they all actually secretly are. Certain paths start to break your heart instead of your brain. (I'm looking at you, Nageki and Ryouta.) Then, if you get all the standard endings, it unlocks a final route with a sudden turn into a dark, deeply emotional horror/mystery that completely defies description.

In short, you laugh at the very premise of this game, and you are right to do so. However, like some sort of Trojan Pigeon, that goofy exterior is used to deliver one of the greatest visual novels, if not one of the greatest games of any genre ever made. I'm serious. So is the game, eventually.

(I do have to dock a point or two for the combined total of some minor text errors and gameplay bugs in the current version.  However, please do not let this dissuade you.  Still HIGHLY recommended.)

reviewText: Hatoful Boyfriend is the visual novel that got me to start reading visual novels a few years ago, and along with Katawa Shoujo, showed me how genuinely well written they can be. With the absurd premise of dating talking, oversized birds in a high school called St. Pigeonation's, you'd be forgiven for assuming that game was entirely parodical. Yet the stories of characters such as Nageki and Ryouta become genuine tearjerkers towards their conclusions, and the game gradually unlocks more sinister stories as you go, with Iwamine Shuu's being the darkest of all normal routes by far, with some very creepy overtones and disturbing implications.\n\nThen you complete enough routes to unlock the Bad Boys Love" (I have no idea why it was called this) mode

reviewText: Hatoful Boyfriend isn't just the hilarious pigeon dating sim you see on the surface. Radical political parties, genocide, experimentation, biological warfare, murder, pudding--just to name a few--are all themes you'll encounter in this game.\n\nYou are a human transfer student in a school specifically for birds. Unbeknownst to you, your mission is to woo every bird in the school, albeit one at a time in separate playthroughs. Each bird has different interests, personalities, and backstories, but the more you play, the more you'll realize that they're all intertwined, and that there's something terribly sinister going on at your school behind the scenes. Once you've seduced every bird and achieved every ending, you are rewarded with a chance to fulfill the promise
date:
and solve a mystery that will leave you on the edge of your seat for hours.

Hatoful Boyfriend is beyond deceptive in its marketing as a joke, and I hadn't expected that it would tell a wonderfully written story that would leave me in tears at its end.

--

My only gripe about Hatoful Boyfriend is the spotty save system, as so many others seem to have issues with, too. I would occasionally need to load a save only to find that it would load a background without characters, text, or interface, forcing me to Alt+F4 to leave the game. The save file was forever corrupted, and I would have to restart that particular storyline. The dating playthroughs are short enough to finish in single sittings, but the finale can take hours to finish. I would recommend playing the finale only if you know you have a lot of free time ahead of you, at least until the save issues are fixed. I will amend this review should they be resolved.

Oh, and the occasional typo or missing word, but that's not a big deal.

--

Have fun, everybirdie!

reviewText: This is no ordinary pigeon dating simulator. Yes, you can flirt with and persue a bird of your choice, but it's so much more than that. Not only must you choose between Yuuya, the man-about-town and his smooth words, his half-brother Sakuya, the haughty aristocrat with a secret past, or any of the other mysterious and unusual birds at St. Pigeonation's... You must ford the confusing waters of an international conspiracy. Will you join the track team or the student council? Will you encounter the darkness beneath you all? Will you go to the fair with Ryouta, your friend and ally? Or will you take the arm of Shuu, the dastardly and intimidating physician? 10/10 GOTY

reviewText:
Hatoful Boyfriend is a game originally released in 2011 in Japan and has been rereleased globally in 2014 onto Steam.

We have seen various dating simulators on Steam which have been pretty mediocre (not that I have played any of them...). However this game should be the No. 1 priority for Steam users if they are looking into immersing themselves in visual novels for the first time. Of course, users can play visual novels that are not on Steam such as Katawa Shoujo (which is exceptionally good by the way), but we should seize the opportunity Lord GabeN has given us, allowing us to play dating simulators on the legendary platform known as Steam. So don't lose this opportunity!

Hatoful Boyfriend is a visual novel game in which the player dates pigeons. Although this may sound like an unusual concept, we gamers are always looking out on the market for the latest innovative games which bring new concepts and ideas to the congested video game market. Although the visual novel genre isn't especially innovative, the idea of having a romantic relationship between the protagonist, you, and various male pigeons is certainly innovative. Therefore I am giving this game a thumbs up.

This may seem like a review just to laud the game's innovation and creativity. However, the gameplay and graphics are also up to par with the other releases which have come out at around the same time as this game. Even though this game is a visual novel, it provides immersive gameplay which will keep players like myself hooked on for hours at a time. The soundtrack for the game is one of the best in the market, which is why I purchased the Digital Deluxe version of the game, which includes the song's soundtrack!

Positives
Exceptional graphics (Can be considered a benchmarking tool similar to what Ryse: Son of Rome was on PC).
Exceptional storyline (Not as good as Barbie Dreamhouse Party but still better than The Last of Us).
Exceptional optimization (Runs better than Assassin's Creed: Unity).
Exceptional gameplay (Combine Flappy Bird and Angry Birds).
Exceptional characters (Especially Okosan).
Mixed
No nudity (Depends whether you like nude pigeons or not. If you do, I do not know if there is an uncensored version out there...).
Negative
No anti-aliasing (I feel like the graphics could be even more amazing if there was some anti-aliasing).
Not enough pigeons (I need more to suppress my desires...).
Even though this game has some negatives about it, I would still consider it to be GOTY. We all know there is no such thing as a perfect video game. The positives heavily outweigh the negatives and that is all that matters. So therefore, I hope that you have carefully read this review and will pick this game up as soon as possible. If you are not overly convinced that this game is amazing yet, I suggest reading the other 1,500 or so reviews on the store page!

8/8









(I hope you didn't expect this review to be legitimate XD)

If you love visual novels, buy this game.

reviewText:
Hatoful Boyfriend is a game originally released in 2011 in Japan and has been rereleased globally in 2014 onto Steam.

We have seen various dating simulators on Steam which have been pretty mediocre (not that I have played any of them...). However this game should be the No. 1 priority for Steam users if they are looking into immersing themselves in visual novels for the first time. Of course, users can play visual novels that are not on Steam such as Katawa Shoujo (which is exceptionally good by the way), but we should seize the opportunity Lord GabeN has given us, allowing us to play dating simulators on the legendary platform known as Steam. So don't lose this opportunity!

Hatoful Boyfriend is a visual novel game in which the player dates pigeons. Although this may sound like an unusual concept, we gamers are always looking out on the market for the latest innovative games which bring new concepts and ideas to the congested video game market. Although the visual novel genre isn't especially innovative, the idea of having a romantic relationship between the protagonist, you, and various male pigeons is certainly innovative. Therefore I am giving this game a thumbs up.

This may seem like a review just to laud the game's innovation and creativity. However, the gameplay and graphics are also up to par with the other releases which have come out at around the same time as this game. Even though this game is a visual novel, it provides immersive gameplay which will keep players like myself hooked on for hours at a time. The soundtrack for the game is one of the best in the market, which is why I purchased the Digital Deluxe version of the game, which includes the song's soundtrack!

Positives
Exceptional graphics (Can be considered a benchmarking tool similar to what Ryse: Son of Rome was on PC).
Exceptional storyline (Not as good as Barbie Dreamhouse Party but still better than The Last of Us).
Exceptional optimization (Runs better than Assassin's Creed: Unity).
Exceptional gameplay (Combine Flappy Bird and Angry Birds).
Exceptional characters (Especially Okosan).
Mixed
No nudity (Depends whether you like nude pigeons or not. If you do, I do not know if there is an uncensored version out there...).
Negative
No anti-aliasing (I feel like the graphics could be even more amazing if there was some anti-aliasing).
Not enough pigeons (I need more to suppress my desires...).
Even though this game has some negatives about it, I would still consider it to be GOTY. We all know there is no such thing as a perfect video game. The positives heavily outweigh the negatives and that is all that matters. So therefore, I hope that you have carefully read this review and will pick this game up as soon as possible. If you are not overly convinced that this game is amazing yet, I suggest reading the other 1,500 or so reviews on the store page!

8/8









(I hope you didn't expect this review to be legitimate XD)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Hatoful Boyfriend. Guess what? You date birds. It might sound like any visual novel on the market, but it's quite different.
You may be turned off. But don't be. It's one the best $10 (Or $15) dollars you'll ever spend.

Gameplay (9/10):
+Straightfoward Visual Novel gameplay.
+Mutiple Endings. (Including more then 1 for several characters)
+Ability to skip ahead.
+Has a basic stat system.
+Good for a quick game, an average playthrough lasts around 5-20 minutes.
+-Mutiple playthroughs to unlock some new (but small) features.
-Gets boring at times, especially after most endings have been found.
-There is no bird sex.

Graphics (8/10):
+Nothing to complain about.
+Human portraits look nice.
-Limited backgrounds for certain routes.

Sound (7/10):
+It's okay.
+Great music, especially for certain characters.
-Gets a little tedious.

Story (10/10):
+Deeper then expected.
+Emotional. You will /never/ find a game ever that makes you cry over certain endings.
+Interesting endings and lore.
+Branching story. Techincally.
+-Mutiple playthroughs to understand the full story.
-Timeline is a bit confusing.

Overall, I really like Hatoful Boyfriend. I've never been a visual novel person, but it's truly done something that toys with the emotions and does some beautiful storytelling. I'd recommend picking up the collector's edition if you truly like it. 9/10

DayZ Review Gimmick: Coo! 9/10

reviewText:
You think you're going to get a good laugh from this game.  You think you're going to see some puns, date some pigeons, have some lighthearted fun.  You would be correct!
However.. you will also start to care about these birds.  These characters will grow on you.  And then the story will turn.  Most of these endings somehow caused me to feel more emotions than I care to admit.  Better yet- once you unlock the BBL route you're in for a surprise.  Watch as a dating sim turns into a sort of mystery game with one of the most compelling stories I've seen in a while.

Overall I am plesantly surprised with this game, It's quickly become my favorite.  I HIGHLY reccomend to anyone that loves a good story, the writing is amazing and the character development is great.  Characters aren't as flat as they might seem at first glance!  There is a manga as well as drama CDs out there for this title, along with a sequel.  I can only hope the next game comes to steam ASAP!

reviewText:
When I first saw this game, my thoughts were: “what even”. When I bought and played the game, my thoughts were “what EVEN”. Now, after finishing it (in multiple ways!) and reviewing it, my thoughts are “WHAT EVEN”.

I just. What. What even?

So it’s a visual novel. About dating birds. As a human girl. In a school for birds. And you WILL adore the birds, fall in love with the birds, cry at the birds, and then stare at the credits in disbelief because did all of that just happen in the span of an hour?

And then you’ll do all of it again. Seven times.

For real though, this game is brilliant. That said, it is definitely not the best game ever. It does manage to be humorous and serious at the same time, and generally at the right times (at least to one familiar with Japanese storytelling conventions).

The downside is the length: in terms of raw content, Hatoful Boyfriend falls a bit short. It’s true there are eight character routes, plus a couple alternatives and extras, but each route only takes about forty to sixty minutes to complete, and that time gets progressively shorter each time you play: a lot of the text is exactly the same regardless of route taken. Aside from taking different classes each day – which there aren’t that many – the contents of the game won’t change much until about 3/4ths through, where you’re finally locked into a specific route.

Still, the story of the game is very engaging. Though the premise and the world is built on humor, the story takes itself very seriously. Each character is fully fleshed out and their routes just sweep you along for the adventure, and the setting the game builds is solid and easy to get into once you accept the wacky premise. The writing itself isn’t exactly superb, but I dare you to name a VN that has that. What matters is that the humor actually manages to be funny, the emotional scenes are actually touching, and the happy scenes are sweet but not over the top. The final product feels very genuine, and that makes up for its shortcomings.

Play this game. You will only regret not playing it sooner.

reviewText: A well written visual novel, with all those heart warming moments, and sad endings, only with Birds. Lots of Puns, good humor and a lot of references to other anime and visual novels. Some routes have more comedy, some are seroius, some are romantic. All the characters are interesting and each route was enjoyable. There is a hidden Dark route after completing all the main charcter routes. This one was especially good, a good tear jerker. Overall a very enjoyable game, Don't just dismiss because of the gag with birds, which i think it improves over normal visual novels. If you want to start getting into visual novels, I recomend starting here. Good luck dating those avian beauties!

reviewText:
I had always secretly wanted this game just by how ridiculous this game is. Evidently there was good reason, as you progress through the game, making choices, interacting with possible husbandoves, and taken twists and turns, the experience overall is ridiculous.
It is a fun game, and great that it offers a fast forward option when you want to skip sections you have read already (such as the beginning).  Progressing through the story isn't terribly long for most endings, and trying to get each birdies ending is fairly straight forward.  This game is easily replayable, especially when you unlock more endings, and can easily get you hooked.  I suggest buying it on sale, however full price isn't terrible either.
My only quarrel is sometimes getting a full ending for a character may not always be clear cut, and thus having to restart a new game may be cumborsome, and one of the endings took a little longer than I would have liked (regardless of how interesting it got).
It's a great game and earns and 8 out of 10 stars.
Something Everbirdie would love, so go find your husbandove

reviewText:
When I first saw this game, my thoughts were: “what even”. When I bought and played the game, my thoughts were “what EVEN”. Now, after finishing it (in multiple ways!) and reviewing it, my thoughts are “WHAT EVEN”.

I just. What. What even?

So it’s a visual novel. About dating birds. As a human girl. In a school for birds. And you WILL adore the birds, fall in love with the birds, cry at the birds, and then stare at the credits in disbelief because did all of that just happen in the span of an hour?

And then you’ll do all of it again. Seven times.

For real though, this game is brilliant. That said, it is definitely not the best game ever. It does manage to be humorous and serious at the same time, and generally at the right times (at least to one familiar with Japanese storytelling conventions).

The downside is the length: in terms of raw content, Hatoful Boyfriend falls a bit short. It’s true there are eight character routes, plus a couple alternatives and extras, but each route only takes about forty to sixty minutes to complete, and that time gets progressively shorter each time you play: a lot of the text is exactly the same regardless of route taken. Aside from taking different classes each day – which there aren’t that many – the contents of the game won’t change much until about 3/4ths through, where you’re finally locked into a specific route.

Still, the story of the game is very engaging. Though the premise and the world is built on humor, the story takes itself very seriously. Each character is fully fleshed out and their routes just sweep you along for the adventure, and the setting the game builds is solid and easy to get into once you accept the wacky premise. The writing itself isn’t exactly superb, but I dare you to name a VN that has that. What matters is that the humor actually manages to be funny, the emotional scenes are actually touching, and the happy scenes are sweet but not over the top. The final product feels very genuine, and that makes up for its shortcomings.

Play this game. You will only regret not playing it sooner.

reviewText:
Listen, I know.
It's a visual-novel-dating-sim thing, featuring birds.
It's one of those things that sounds like a game played by straw-man nerd losers in a cartoon.
However, it's a surprisingly engaging and deep story, with a level of content connectedness that is truly excessive.
Excessive because it all works so stupidly well.
I went into this thinking it was going to be a silly, stupid, amusing romp.
I emerged feeling 100% on board with calling it art, even to the point of being comfortable actively endorsing people play the game, despite the, uh, unsavory impression it may make to say No really

reviewText:
I originally wanted this game as a joke. I never expected to get this attached to birds.

I'll go on ahead and say you don't do much apart from choosing different options, so if you want a game with a lot of story, it's recommended to buy this while it's on sale.

I'm not really sure I should call this game a dating sim, but I've come to like most of the characters as I've played through it.  Though Okosan's route is the most humorous, I'd recommend you to choose a different route first, as quite a few argue Okosan isn't a good representation of Hatoful Boyfriend. The game's fairly light until you get to Hurtful Boyfriend/Bad Boys Love, which does take a bit of time to get through.

Though I've enjoyed the game, I wouldn't recommend it to someone who likes games like shooters.

reviewText:
So the question is: Which love story will you fall for.
It started all with a joke. People laughed and pushed you to a direction you didn't expect. I mean pidgeons, birds, animals. What madness is that. You gave in and went onto a journey, that transformed into a life experience. Is it the bird you follow or is there more to it. Are you the human in the story or aren't you more like a bird imprisoned inside a human. Serously I cannot distinguish where the character ends and where the bird starts. It is the most important experience you will ever experience, if you let the bird inside you awake to its full potential. Never have I ever seen a better game to cross the boundaries between human and bird than this gem of a game.
I would never be able to stop it, if my real relationship wouldn't have dragged me out violently. I mean serously this lovestory is insane. And I haven't even seen the dark corners of the world.

+HD Quality birds
+Well rounded story arc
+Deep and well developed characters
+well situated and beautiful music
+pidgeon jokes at everyy corner

-you loose track of time, since you don't want to stop
-I freaked out at night and was scared. I hope the birds won't do anything to me now.
10/10

reviewText:
I have achieved every route and I STILL play this from time to time. It's that good.

The world has just gone bird brained! You are a Human girl priveldged enough to go to a genius academy with amazing winged creatures and you have a chance to fall in love with all of them. The Teacher and Doctor are included in that mix as well as a few surprises. It plays exactly as expected with tons of feathers thrown in the mix. Quirky, fun, and it has one hell of a sub-story.

You know what they say... Birds of a feather flock together and I'm flocking and sticking my thumbs up for this game!

reviewText:
Thirteen hours. Thirteen hours in less than three days I have logged into this game. Never have I been so drawn into pigeons.

Like everyone else here, I was drawn in by the promise of a silly dating SIM involving birds. I didn't expect this game to be anything intensely amazing. So, when I began, though I had read plenty of reviews, I did not take too many of them that seriously. At first I wasn't overly impressed. The storyline itself seemed solid, though a bit vauge, and the choices that you are allowed in the game are relatively few. It's more a reading adventure than anything, and I quickly learned how to make each bird like me. However, the storyline wasn't nearly so well made as the reviews had spoken of. I had my favorites, of course, but the game seemed a little flat and lacking even at the deepest stories (my personal favorites are Nageki's and Sakuya's), and I disliked the lack of ability to interact with other birds while trying to woo a specific fowl.

And then, though tenacity and determination, I got through all 14 endings, and everything changed.

I won't say anything about the BBL ending. It needs to be played to be appreciated. But this story? This entire game is a work of art. I sat for three hours straight, playing the ending alone, just gaping at how well and perfectly everything fit together, with all the character interaction I had been missing and the complex storylines and depth that the game has been lauded for.

This game is worth every penny.

There are some technical difficulties I'm not impressed with. The save feature, for me, was a joke. Half the time the game would glitch and freeze when a save point was loaded, and made me have to go through and replay the game again. I saw the intro at least 12 times, which is more times than anyone needs to be introduced to each bird and can get sickeningly boring. The game also had a tendancy to freeze at important decisions, making me have to replay yet again, so it became a real effort in patience trying to deal with these glitches without throwing it out. All through the three hour ending, I was on the edge of my seat half expecting to have to go through most of it again because it might decide to freeze on me. Thankfully, it did not do any such thing, and I was able to enjoy myself through the massive and bright storyline *ehehe*.

I also don't reccomend this game for those who are sensitive to gore and murder. Not because it shows any, because it doesn't, but some of these storylines get rather... descriptive of these things. I wouldn't say it's anything for kids, for sure.

Even with these issues, if you're on the fence, tip over and fly. You won't regret it.

~Kero

reviewText: This game was absolutely not what I expected. I don't want to spoil anything...but the content is a lot darker than one would expect from a bird dating sim. I had a lot of fun. Laughed a lot, cried a little. Playing the game over and over to get all the achievements was pretty monotonous, but it was still a good time.\n\nIf you're looking for a ridiculous game with some serious moments, this game is a good choice. Your friends will never have a worse opinion of you, though. Mine think I'm garbage, now. 10/10 worth it
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I recommend this! Well, if you're okay with the basic premise: a light-hearted, mostly-text adventure game (visual novel with several courses) in which you play a human girl transferred to a school of intelligent pigeons. If none of that bothers you, you'll find the rest of the game to be very well developed, with a lot of thought and humor.\n\nTo enjoy Hatoful Boyfriend the most, you will want to see multiple endings. There's one specific ending that's really great, but you need to play through other endings first to get it. If necessary, look up spoiler-free instructions on how to get the BBL ending. Don't give up on Hatoful until you see that one.

reviewText: I can't believe the day has come when I can unironically recommend a video game about dating pigeons, but to be fair I did also unironically recommend Euro Truck Simulator 2.\n\nHatoful Boyfriend (if you're wondering, hatoful" could be read as "heartful" or "hurtful"; and also triples as a pun to the Japanese kanji for pigeon) shows that no matter how silly the premise
date: you can still make a great story out of it. What originally started out as a visual novel about dating pigeons
recommended: eventually becomes a visual novel about dating pigeons with deep and complex personalities.\n\nThe game (or should I say the visual novel) itself is nothing complex
hoursPlayed: the closest thing to gameplay here is making a decision. Though your decision will ultimately decide who you choose to get close with and how the game ends.\n\nSpeaking of the story
voteText: it is quite entertaining. The writing is fantastic
helpfulPercent: and all of the characters have their own lovable quirks
votesHelpful: in fact the route you take can vastly affect the mood of the story. After going on a certain route
votesTotal: you can do the hidden route which unless you've gotten all the ending (which includes both the normal and true ending for every character) you won't see the epilogue. Getting all of the ending means you have to read through a lot of the things you've read before
votesFunny:
there is a fast forward button; but sometimes new dialogues could appear in a scene that you expected to play as usual.

Overall Hatoful Boyfriend is an entertaining visual novel about dating pigeons...

That was anti-climatic."

reviewText:
I originally wanted this game as a joke. I never expected to get this attached to birds.

I'll go on ahead and say you don't do much apart from choosing different options, so if you want a game with a lot of story, it's recommended to buy this while it's on sale.

I'm not really sure I should call this game a dating sim, but I've come to like most of the characters as I've played through it.  Though Okosan's route is the most humorous, I'd recommend you to choose a different route first, as quite a few argue Okosan isn't a good representation of Hatoful Boyfriend. The game's fairly light until you get to Hurtful Boyfriend/Bad Boys Love, which does take a bit of time to get through.

Though I've enjoyed the game, I wouldn't recommend it to someone who likes games like shooters.
